componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's program. [Operator Instructions] 
It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Tom McCallum. Please go ahead.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the fourth quarter and full year of fiscal 2016. Let me first say on behalf of all Red Hat associates, our thoughts and prayers are with everyone impacted by the event in Brusse
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the fourth quarter and full year of fiscal 2016. Let me first say on behalf of all Red Hat associates, our thoughts and prayers are with everyone impacted by the event in Brussels today. 
Moving on to the call. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; Frank Calderoni, Executive Vice President Operations and CFO. 
Our earnings press release was issued today after the market closed and may be downloaded from redhat.com on the Investor Relations page. Also on this page, you'll be able to find a copy of today's prepared remarks, a schedule of currency rates and a slide deck with financial highlights and supplemental metrics that include a reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial results. 
During this call, we may make forward-looking statements about our future financial performance and other events or trends, including guidance for our the full year and first quarter of fiscal 2017. These statements are only predictions that are based on what we believe today, and actual results may differ materially. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that could affect our financial results and the performance of our business, and which we discuss in detail in our filings with the SEC, including today's press release and the risk factors and other information contained in our most recently filed Form 10-Q and Form 10-K. Red Hat assumes no obligation to update any of these forward-looking statements we may make on today's call. 
With that, let me turn it over to Jim.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to everyone joining us on today's call. The fourth quarter was a strong finish to another great year for Red Hat and our momentum and outlook are strong as we begin the new fiscal year. Our results reflect the fac
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to everyone joining us on today's call. The fourth quarter was a strong finish to another great year for Red Hat and our momentum and outlook are strong as we begin the new fiscal year. Our results reflect the fact that enterprises are increasingly adopting hybrid cloud infrastructures and open source technology. And they are turning to Red Hat as the strategic partners they do so. 
We exceeded guidance across all our financial metrics in the fourth quarter in addition to setting new records in milestones for the year. Here are a few highlights.
First, the fourth quarter marked our 56th consecutive quarter of revenue growth, which contributed to Red Hat's first year of crossing the $2 billion in total revenue milestone. Second, we drove accelerated full year revenue growth in both the infrastructure related technologies at 18% constant-currency growth compared to 13% in the prior year and the application development in emerging technologies at 46% constant currency, up from 43% last year. Third, strong sales execution led to record total backlog of over $2.1 billion at the end of the year. And fourth, we delivered full year revenue growth of 21% in constant currency, non-GAAP operating income growth of 16% and operating cash flow growth of 15%. 
Looking at our large deal wins for the quarter, we saw strength as it related to the volume of large deals, the size of the deals as well as the breadth of technologies that were purchased. Here are some of the highlights of our top 30 largest deals. All of them are greater than $1 million. In fact, we closed 3 times that many delivering more than 90 deals in excess of $1 million in Q4. We also had a record 14 deals in Q4 that were in excess of $5 million. Of these deals, we closed 15 in excess of $10 million, which is a record number of deals over $10 million for any quarter. 
Cross-selling was strong with 80% of the deals, including one or more components from our group of application development and emerging technologies offerings. Middleware in particular had strong traction in our largest deals with 75%, including a middleware component. This type of traction demonstrates our continued share gain in the middleware space. 
Our emerging cloud technologies also gained traction in our top deals, including a multimillion dollar win for OpenStack that we expect will be one of the largest installs of OpenStack once it's fully implemented. 
The top vertical for the quarter was telecommunications where we closed a number of deals with several global telecommunications providers. The next highest vertical on the top deals was financial services. 
In addition to our success on-premise, we continue to be very active with our partners in the certified cloud and service provider program or CCSP. We've added more partners in FY '16 and now have approximately 150 certified partners around the globe. In Q4, we further expanded our technology offerings that can be consumed in the cloud. For instance, RHEL on demand is activated on Azure in February. OpenShift, our past solution and our storage technology will be added to the Google Cloud and RHEL OpenStack platform is now available at Rackspace as a managed service. In fact, we already have our first reference customer using this service, TV Bank. 
The CCSP program has generated over $100 million this fiscal year and grew approximately 90% year-over-year. During meetings, Frank and I hosted over the quarter, investors have asked whether the public cloud is a positive driver for Red Hat. We firmly believe that it will be a hybrid cloud world where applications will run across all 4 footprints, physical, virtual, public cloud and private cloud. Furthermore, we are providing technologies that enable choice and consistencies across all 4 environments and we enhanced this value with application development technologies storage and management. The public cloud specifically activate channel for us and it is part of the value we bring to customers. Beyond expansion of our relationship with cloud providers and high-growth revenue results, let me share with you some customer data from our largest public cloud partner. 
First is a channel partner. This public cloud has been a great resource for us to reach new customers, including small and medium-sized businesses. We see approximately half the revenue from this public cloud comes from usage totaling less than $5,000 per customer in the quarter. This group most likely include small and medium-sized businesses, test and development environments, business divisions and start up companies. Second, the public cloud enables our existing customers, additional choice on where to run their workloads. The other approximately half of the revenue with this cloud vendor comes from existing customers. We match this data with the on-premise purchasing patterns of subscriptions for these existing customers. What we found was that this group of customers has continued to expand their on-premise subscription purchases while they are also rapidly utilizing the public cloud environment for additional RHEL workload. This reinforces our view that it will be a hybrid cloud world and that Red Hat can continue to expand our wallet share as we provide choice and consistency to customers across all 4 footprints. 
As I noted previously, we achieved higher rates of revenue growth across our infrastructure, application development and emerging technologies during fiscal '16 which represents strong sales growth across all 4 footprints. Within the application development and emerging technologies, our fast-growing OpenStack private cloud, OpenShift PaaS and CloudForms' cloud management product line. We've made significant progress this past year, expanding our position in this part of the hybrid cloud environment and driving faster adoption. Here are some highlights. 
We closed a number of large production deployments and hundreds of initial deployments along with hundreds of proof of concepts. Our sales traction has led to lighthouse customer wins with Cox Enterprises, Union Bank and FICO, just to name a few from FY '16. We doubled the number of Red Hat OpenStack certified professionals worldwide over the past year and we have trained over 10,000 customers on OpenStack in calendar 2015 alone. Companies wanting to bring Red Hat OpenStack to their IT environments can look to a growing pool of qualified professionals to make it happen. Our combination of training certification in Professional Services is speeding adoption at this technology. We're excited about our accomplishments today. 
Our revenue from private infrastructures as a service, PaaS and cloud management technologies is growing at nearly twice as fast as our public cloud revenue did when it was at the same size. We believe FY '17 will be another year of significant revenue growth with new customer adoption and further expansion with existing ones. 
In summary, customers are demanding technologies that modernize the development, deployment and life cycle management of applications across hybrid cloud environments. Many are relying on Red Hat to provide both the infrastructure and application development platforms to run their enterprise applications consistently and reliably across physical, virtual, private and public cloud environments. This has positioned Red Hat for solid growth in fiscal '17 that Frank will detail in a moment. We continue to focus on capturing market share in each of the new high-growth market areas in which we compete. To achieve this goal, our plan is to continue to invest for the long-term growth of our open hybrid cloud technologies with enterprises and service provider customers. 
Before turning the call over to Frank, I want to congratulate and thank our 8800 Red Hat Associates around the globe for their efforts to achieve the $2 billion revenue milestone and position us for further growth next year and beyond. On a final note, I hope many of you will be able to join us for the June 30 Analyst Day at the Red Hat Summit in San Francisco. It will be a great opportunity to learn more about our strategic direction and innovative technologies. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. We executed well on the fourth quarter and throughout FY '16. We effectively managed our investment in expanding our open hybrid cloud opportunities with strong execution while delivering profitable growth. We exceeded our guidance, which
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. We executed well on the fourth quarter and throughout FY '16. We effectively managed our investment in expanding our open hybrid cloud opportunities with strong execution while delivering profitable growth. We exceeded our guidance, which led to double-digit growth in revenue, non-GAAP operating income, operating cash flow and total backlog for the fiscal year. The fourth quarter also marked our fifth consecutive quarter of 20% plus total revenue growth on a constant currency basis. We are proud to be one of the very few software companies who can deliver this type of growth at over $2 billion in scale and it is a testament to our leadership position, business model and market opportunity. 
Here are some of the Q4 financial highlights. We were pleased to generate total revenue of $544 million, which grew 21% on a year-over-year basis in constant currency or 17% in U.S. dollars. Taking into account the fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, total revenue would have been $17 million or 360 basis points higher, using the rates from Q4 of last year. Due to the continued high FX volatility, I will provide both U.S. dollar and constant currency results for the quarter using the rates from Q4 last year where it's appropriate. Our revenue performance for the quarter exceeded the high end of our guidance by approximately $5 million on a U.S. dollar basis. Both subscription and service revenue was stronger than forecasted. All of our major geographies recorded strong growth with the Americas up 19%, EMEA up 24%, Asia-Pacific up 26% on a constant currency basis. The main driver of our total revenue growth was subscription revenue, up $480 million, an increase of 22% constant currency and 18% year-over-year in U.S. dollars. This renewable revenue stream now constitutes 88% of total revenue. 
We continue to drive higher growth across our technology portfolio. The subscription revenue for infrastructure related offerings was $391 million, an increase of 18% in constant currency and 15% year-over-year in U.S. dollars. Our subscription revenue for application development related in emerging technologies offerings was $89 million, an increase of 43% in constant currency and 38% year-over-year in U.S. dollars. Application development related and emerging technologies revenue was approximately 16% of total revenue, and that's up 250 basis points from the year-ago quarter. On a non-GAAP basis, operating income was $124 million and grew 13%. Non-GAAP operating margin was 22.9%. And as a reminder, non-GAAP operating income adjust for noncash share-based compensation expense, amortization of intangible assets and transaction costs related to business combination. These non-GAAP operating margin was modestly above our guidance while it included a full quarter of expenses and investments related to the Ansible acquisition. 
As our results have demonstrated and combined with the growth drivers that Jim just discussed, we believe we can further expand our market share gain with additional investments in our hybrid cloud capabilities. In Q4, we were proactive on our fiscal 2017 investments due to the strong momentum of our business. We added approximately 480 associates this quarter, mainly in sales, customer support, consulting and R&D. For the full fiscal year, we have added approximately 1,500 associates for a total of approximately 8,800 associates globally. 
After adjusting for noncash share-based compensation expense, amortization of intangible assets, transaction costs related to business combinations and noncash interest expense related to the convertible debt discount, non-GAAP diluted earnings per share came to $0.52 per share. That's $0.05 above the guidance we provided in December. In addition to the higher revenue and disciplined spending, which drove the $0.01 per share of upside, we benefited from a discrete tax benefit of approximately $0.04 per share related to the reauthorization of the R&D tax credit. 
Next, let me discuss our annual backlog that we disclosed with the fourth quarter results. First, total backlog was up 15% year-over-year on February 29 for a record balance in excess of $2.13 billion in U.S. dollars. On a constant currency basis, total backlog growth would have exceeded 16%. We define total backlog at the value of noncancelable subscriptions and service agreements including our total deferred revenue, which is billed, plus the value of noncancelable subscriptions and service agreements to be billed in the future, which are not reflected in our financial statements. 
Here are the component pieces. The portion of a total backlog that has been billed is total deferred, which is $1.72 billion at the end of fiscal 2016 and this was up 16% year-over-year. On a constant currency basis, the total deferred revenue would have been up 18%. The portion of total backlog to be billed in the future or our off-balance sheet backlog was in excess of $410 million compared to an excess of $380 million last fiscal year. This was up over 8% year-over-year in U.S. dollars, and on a constant currency basis, the off-balance sheet backlog would have been up more than 10%. It is worth noting that the portion of off-balance sheet backlog to be billed in the next 12 months was in excess of $275 million and this was up approximately $45 million or 20% from fiscal 2015. 
The combination of deferred revenue and off-balance sheet backlog provides us with forward-looking visibility into a significant portion of FY '17 revenue as well as contributing to revenue beyond FY '17. The average contract length in the quarter was 22 months and for the full year, the average deal length return to the historic 21 month duration after being elevated at 22 months in FY '15.
 Deferred revenue is also a component of our billing proxy. Our preferred view of billing is the rolling 4 quarter's billing proxy, which is calculated by adding revenue, plus the change in total deferred on the cash flow statement for the last 4 quarters. On a rolling 4 quarter basis, the fourth quarter billing proxy was $578 million, that's up 12% year-over-year and on a constant currency basis, this metric would have been up 17% year-over-year. We ended the quarter with cash and investments of approximately $2 billion and during the quarter, we returned $114 million to shareholders from repurchasing approximately 1.6 million shares of stock. We had approximately $237 million remaining on the current share repurchase authorization at the end of the quarter. For the full year, we returned $263 million to shareholders from repurchasing approximately 3.5 million shares of stock. And over the past 5 years, our repurchase program have reduced our fully diluted share count by over 10 million shares or approximately 6%. 
Operating cash flow of $247 million for the quarter was up 14% year-over-year and a record for any quarter. Strong collections contributed to this result with FX adjusted day sales outstanding at 61 days. This is down from 62 days a year ago quarter. 
Now to briefly recap and summarize the highlights for the full fiscal year. Total revenue grew $2.05 billion, that's up 21% year-over-year in constant currency or up 15% in U.S. dollars. Subscription revenue grew $1.8 billion, an increase of 22% in constant currency or 16% in U.S. dollars. Subscription revenue for infrastructure related offerings was $1.48 billion, that's up 18% in constant currency and 12% U.S. dollars. Subscription revenue for application development and emerging technologies was $323 million, up 46% in constant currency and 37% in U.S. dollars. For FY '16 application development and emerging technology subscriptions contributed 16% of total revenue, and that's up from 13% last fiscal year. Non-GAAP operating income grew 16%. Full year fiscal '16 non-GAAP operating margin was 30 basis points higher than FY '15 and included the dilutive impact from the Ansible acquisition. Non-GAAP EPS for the full year was $1.91. That's up 19% over the prior year. 
Overall, our priorities to continue to make smart investments, focus on long-term objectives and remain the open source market leader are proving to be effective. We remain highly focused on strong execution across all areas of business. 
I will now review the metrics for business momentum and talk renewals in the quarter. Across all geographies, we saw continued growth in our bookings. This quarter, 64% of bookings came from the Americas, 23% from EMEA, 13% from Asia Pacific versus 63, 25, 12 split in Q4 of last year. The Q4 sales route to market mix was 71% from the channel and 29% from our direct sales force, and that's compared to 68 32 split in Q4 of last year. For the full fiscal year, we surpassed our multiyear annual goal with a 72-28 split. This quarter, we once again renewed all the deals in our top 25 deals metrics. The total subscription value of these top 25 renewals was approximately 120% of the prior value. Our ability to renew and increase our wallet share with large customers demonstrates Red Hat's increasing strategic importance with customers. This fiscal year, we renewed all the deals in the top 25 deals metric per quarter, renewing all of our deals in each quarter will upsell growth between 115% to 120% for this metric. Over the past 5 years, we've had seamless success renewing 498 out of 500 top deals and this is a phenomenal track record. While we want never want to lose a deal, if we do so, we never give up trying to win back the business. This quarter, I am pleased to report that we closed a multimillion dollar win back of 1 of these 2 former top deals from the 500 deals we reported. We won back this deal on RHEL because of our award-winning support and expanded portfolio of technologies. In addition to now running RHEL, this customer's relying on Red Hat to help modernize application development with Red Hat JBoss middleware and to realize the benefits from hybrid cloud computing with our OpenStack technology. Congratulations to the accounting for an exceptional job of positioning Red Hat to win and expanding our footprint with this customer. 
Now I'd like to turn to guidance. Our outlook assumes current business conditions and foreign currency. We are forecasting our full year revenue guidance to be $2.380 billion to $2.420 billion. That's up approximately 18% at the high-end of the range. Our non-GAAP operating margin forecasts reflects our increased hiring in sales, R&D, services and support at the end of FY '16 and our plan to continue to invest in business and emerging technologies as well as the full year impact of ongoing operational expenses from the Ansible acquisition. We expect operating income to grow by 14% to 16%, with an operating margin of approximately 23.2%. Our plan includes adding approximately 1,400 net new associates or 16% headcount growth, down from 20% headcount growth in FY '16. We expect full year non-GAAP earnings per share to be approximately $2.22 to $2.26 per share, assuming a $1 million to $2 million per quarter forecast for a net other income. A lower annual effective tax rate of 27% and approximately 184 million diluted share. At the top end of the guidance, this would be an 18% growth in earnings per share. On a GAAP basis, we estimate annual stock compensation expenses of approximately $180 million and annual amortization expense of approximately $29 million. GAAP fully diluted EPS guidance includes noncash interest expense, which is related to the convertible debt discount of approximately $19 million. Operating cash flow is expected to grow in the range from $800 million to $820 million. This range includes a headwind of approximately $10 million for increased cash taxes as the company continues to drive greater profitability. For those of you who try to model billings metrics, we would expect the same business flow in our renewal subscription model as in the past. We expect both bookings and billings to repeat their historic pattern of being lowest in Q1 and growing --  going forward to the end of the highest level in Q4. 
For Q1 specifically, we offer the following outlook. We expect revenue to be in the range of $558 million to $566 million, which is up 18% in U.S. dollars at the high-end of the range. One should note that FY '16 Q1 revenue had a onetime catch up benefit from the CCSP program that will not repeat in Q1 of this year. We expect non-GAAP operating margin of approximately 22% and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.50. 
Consistent with prior practices, I will not forecast quarterly cash flow, but please note that it can be variable depending upon individual payments or receipts. 
Overall, we delivered a strong performance in Q4 and throughout FY '16. We continue to believe there is significant opportunity for Red Hat as IT organizations transition their application development and infrastructure to the hybrid cloud environment. We are very well positioned to deliver an attractive combination of revenue growth, profitability, and cash flow for FY '17. We remain optimistic about the company's long-term opportunity as we are uniquely positioned to further drive the adoption of open source technologies and to enable customers to reap the benefits of hybrid cloud computing. 
Operator, I would now like to turn the call back over to you for the first question.

componenttext: Operator, before we do that, this is Jim Whitehurst back again. It was brought to my attention that I misspoke on one number. The number of deals in excess of $10 million that we closed was 5 ideals, which is a record for any quarter. But it's 5 deals, not 15 and the number is correct on our website. Thank you.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is for Keith. I wanted to ask a question on the billings and I have a follow-up question on OpenStack. First on the quarterly billings. I know, Frank, you refer to the fourth quarter proxy, but on this quarter billings, was there anything from a dura
componenttext: This is for Keith. I wanted to ask a question on the billings and I have a follow-up question on OpenStack. First on the quarterly billings. I know, Frank, you refer to the fourth quarter proxy, but on this quarter billings, was there anything from a duration perspective or a ramping cloud business that caused that number to come in a little bit below consensus?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually the number came in. So the number that we posted from a 7 64 came in probably slightly above the average of consensus. And as you know, we don't guide billings and the consensus numbers do vary widely. So coming in slightly above the average I th
componenttext: Actually the number came in. So the number that we posted from a 7 64 came in probably slightly above the average of consensus. And as you know, we don't guide billings and the consensus numbers do vary widely. So coming in slightly above the average I think, it's kind well positioned there. Just a couple of comments, as I did reflect in the call, the best view of the trends in business is that rolling 4 quarter proxy. As you can see throughout the last year, we've had the rolling 4 quarter proxy be up about 20% from a constant currency basis and I think that's fairly strong from a -- for a $2 billion company. Coming in at about 17%, it's modestly down from what we saw in the past few quarters, but nothing out of the ordinary. This quarter, we had, as Jim mentioned, we have strong renewals, we had up sales in top deals. We did have Q4 had a tough compare as far as what we had in Q4 of last year where the billings were up 26%, but again, I think overall performance was fairly, fairly strong.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016

componenttext: And there's a follow-up?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And a quick follow-up and this sort of relates to margins and may be that to tie it into OpenStack it sounds like you're seeing a lot of momentum on the OpenStack business. And I guess my question is when we look at the margin guidance for next year, whic
componenttext: And a quick follow-up and this sort of relates to margins and may be that to tie it into OpenStack it sounds like you're seeing a lot of momentum on the OpenStack business. And I guess my question is when we look at the margin guidance for next year, which looks to be flat again from the guidance perspective year-over-year in terms of your full year outlook. Is the momentum in OpenStack, is that what's driving increased investments in sales in the field? And when will we -- when should investors start to expect overall margin expansion? Is that after fiscal year '17?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one of the things that -- so a couple of questions there. First, let me start with the comment about the emerging technologies. And as you know, I've been with the company for about 3 quarters and I've been out at various conferences. And one of the th
componenttext: So one of the things that -- so a couple of questions there. First, let me start with the comment about the emerging technologies. And as you know, I've been with the company for about 3 quarters and I've been out at various conferences. And one of the things that I've noticed as part of the company, which I think is very important, is the emerging technology opportunity. And we're early in that, when you start thinking about OpenStack and OpenShift and some of the other emerging technology products that we have, it's important for us to invest in that business in order to see its scale. We just finished a long-range plan. And as we look at the next several years, there's a tremendous amount of opportunity for us and we want to make sure that we're supporting that. So we've done a lot of analysis in the last several weeks, several months in looking at the investments that we have to make. When you start looking at a PaaS implementation or an Infrastructure-as-a-Service implementation, they're firmly complex and we did some analysis to kind of look at what a typical deal in that space would involve and you it could be as short as 12 months as far as the investment up to about 24 months as we go through an initiation, evaluation phase where we're working with the customer, we then have to go through a pilot project period, which is part of the early development We then go into a larger production environment. That will also take a couple of months. And after that, once you start getting that PaaS or the Infrastructure-as-a-Service in place, we then start looking at adding in JBoss and storage. So this process is fairly complex and can be lengthy, and of course, investments associated with that. So [indiscernible] over the last 2 quarters we've increased our spending to support that. And as we look at FY '17, we're doing the same thing there in at the same time, trying to balance those investments. If you look at the overall guidance that we provided, when you adjust for some of the Ansible and also a couple of other minor adjustments like with the cloud business that we had last year, the margins are about flat and so I think that's a fairly good model to have while we're making some of these important strategic investments.

I know in the past you talked about for enterprise workloads. Is there anything that stands out the from that platform? And then maybe just a quick one for Frank. I wonder what your CapEx expectations are for '17.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I'll start on Azure. As you said, it is very, very early days. We have some big-name, permanent, large enterprise customers who are kicking the tires, right? But for those to move that they're enterprise workloads, will take I'll a little while
componenttext: Yes, well, I'll start on Azure. As you said, it is very, very early days. We have some big-name, permanent, large enterprise customers who are kicking the tires, right? But for those to move that they're enterprise workloads, will take I'll a little while, but the fact that there is a lot of interest on what I'll say large enterprise customers I think demonstrate our hypothesis that it's got to be appealing to large enterprises were looking at hybrid cloud environment's. The numbers at this point are tiny, tiny because people are kicking the tires on it. But given the size of the customers of our customers who are looking at moving some workloads makes us feel like it's going to be an important kind of a deployment vehicle for RHEL in our broader stock as we go forward.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the CapEx questions. So in FY '16, we spent above $40 million. We came in below what we had expected so about $10 million in that range. We're going to carry forward some of that $10 million into the new fiscal year. So with that and also lookin
componenttext: As far as the CapEx questions. So in FY '16, we spent above $40 million. We came in below what we had expected so about $10 million in that range. We're going to carry forward some of that $10 million into the new fiscal year. So with that and also looking at the investments that we're making primarily to support some of the level for some of these customers on the emerging products, some IT investments that we're making as we look at scaling the enterprise and then also associated with some of the real estate with the growth that we've had and we'll have in some of the associates that we have across the company, we're looking at a number in the $60 million to $70 million range.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's good to see the momentum in the private cloud and emerging technology, but just going back to core [ph] Linux FY '16 had 18% growth in constant currency versus 15% last year. I'm just wondering what's your expectation for this FY '17 given that now M
componenttext: It's good to see the momentum in the private cloud and emerging technology, but just going back to core [ph] Linux FY '16 had 18% growth in constant currency versus 15% last year. I'm just wondering what's your expectation for this FY '17 given that now Microsoft opened up SQL Server over Linux. And is there any other factors that we should think about for the quarterly next call?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we obviously don't guide at a product level. I mean, we continue to say that we think that Linux can grow kind of in the mid-teens kind of level of growth rates and there are a lot of positive factors, whether that's people move into cloud or things
componenttext: Well, we obviously don't guide at a product level. I mean, we continue to say that we think that Linux can grow kind of in the mid-teens kind of level of growth rates and there are a lot of positive factors, whether that's people move into cloud or things like SQL Server, which I think increases the TAM for Linux and obviously databases typically run on a supported version of Linux. So I think there's a lot of positive growth drivers that continue our momentum in RHEL.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats on a strong finish to the year and the guidance above consensus. Jim, I wanted to go a little bit deeper on that point. So it seemed as though the announcement that Microsoft will come out with a Linux version of SQL Server. By mid-2017 is a pret
componenttext: Congrats on a strong finish to the year and the guidance above consensus. Jim, I wanted to go a little bit deeper on that point. So it seemed as though the announcement that Microsoft will come out with a Linux version of SQL Server. By mid-2017 is a pretty monumental event. And so it's the #1 database in the Gartner quadrant. It's one of the largest infrastructure software revenue streams in the world, but it's only been available on Windows in the past. So it seems we were remarking that the impressive Linux in open source in general is broader than just running RHEL on Azure. And I'm curious how do you interpret that and just how much interest do you expect to see for SQL Server on the next when that product comes out in about a request and that I have a quick follow-up after that.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I've done been deeper search in the database business. I will say I think it reflects Microsoft's recognition that you need to have a product like a database on 1 of the 2 major platforms for -- on the OS side. So Windows just limits you. I th
componenttext: Well, look, I've done been deeper search in the database business. I will say I think it reflects Microsoft's recognition that you need to have a product like a database on 1 of the 2 major platforms for -- on the OS side. So Windows just limits you. I think it demonstrates that even Microsoft recognizes that Linux is a large growing component enterprise footprint. I think it will be helpful for us. I think one of the dings [ph] I would say on Linux in the past has been that the database alternatives are supported database alternatives are pretty pricey. And so I think this will be a net positive for our business. In terms of will people migrate databases. That's a question for Microsoft there. It's not one we looked at separately because we're not in that business. But it think it's just another demonstration that Microsoft recognizes it needs to have its technologies running on Linux just like .NET where we can access millions of .NET developers now. This is just another opportunity for us to expand addressable markets and we can get with Linux.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Mark, you had a quick follow-up?
componenttext: Great. Mark, you had a quick follow-up?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I did. So, Jim, from time to time, you've commented that a few of your products were supply constrained. I think every once in a while either OpenStack or fuse our Red Hat storage, et cetera. Just given the concerns that are out there on the potential pot
componenttext: I did. So, Jim, from time to time, you've commented that a few of your products were supply constrained. I think every once in a while either OpenStack or fuse our Red Hat storage, et cetera. Just given the concerns that are out there on the potential potentially hitting a slower path in the economy, could you just update us on are there any areas of the business that are supply constrained today?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, both OpenStack and OpenShift, our PaaS platform, are supply constrained. When you start actually looking at taking OpenStack and putting it into production in significant ways, that requires a fair amount of work with the customer, and we continue t
componenttext: Well, both OpenStack and OpenShift, our PaaS platform, are supply constrained. When you start actually looking at taking OpenStack and putting it into production in significant ways, that requires a fair amount of work with the customer, and we continue to work to develop those capabilities to do that, but OpenStack engineers at the level to do net new installs are still few and far between. If you know of any, please send them our way. Same with OpenShift around containers, right? Containers in [indiscernible] , which is a 2 key underlying technologies are pretty important technologies right now. They are growing really fast. And so we have to kind of organically build skill to do that. We can't find a system integrator that just has those. And so both of those are supply constrained still.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Raimo Lenschow with Barclays.

componenttext: [indiscernible] staying a little bit on [indiscernible]. Can you comment a little bit where you see from a geographic perspective [indiscernible], your results are pretty strong, but just my first question was around [indiscernible] U.S. [indiscernible] .

componenttext: Raimo, you're breaking up a little bit, but I think you were asking what's the difference between the U.S. and Europe. I guess you, Raimo, the main thing I would say I'd emphasize a lot is that we are I believe that indicator of macro because we do really well in down markets because that's people are looking to carve off costs and start traditional business does well in down markets. And so again, as you saw, we had strength around the world, but I think that has much more to do with our value proposition necessarily than kind of a call one way or another kind of macro IT spending environment.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, by the way, the wind back we talked about lists RHEL in back, but putting that aside and coming back to OpenStack in telco, we actually feel really good about where we are. Recognize we sell products and selling product requires summative making a l
componenttext: Well, by the way, the wind back we talked about lists RHEL in back, but putting that aside and coming back to OpenStack in telco, we actually feel really good about where we are. Recognize we sell products and selling product requires summative making a longer term position to implement a solution. Marantz is still primarily a services company and a lot of people will experiment with a little bit of services to play around with the technology. So I don't see the market as us to being Francis necessarily in telco now. And I think a lot of people are playing around with Professional Services and when they get ready to implement an enterprise product, I think we're incredibly well positioned to Windows, and I think that's part of what we're seeing.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of things I just saw from one of the banks within the last 90 days, there was a survey of IT professionals done specifically around OpenStack and it shows the vendors today, we are at the top of the list as far as the largest vendor from an OpenStack
componenttext: One of things I just saw from one of the banks within the last 90 days, there was a survey of IT professionals done specifically around OpenStack and it shows the vendors today, we are at the top of the list as far as the largest vendor from an OpenStack perspective. And then the FTI, CIOs what their expectation was over the next 2 to 3 years. And if I recall from the survey, it showed Red Hat growing much more so essentially as for us with a preferred vendor's going to be versus some of the others. I think we're well positioned with some of the early work that we've done with many of our customers. Those that have actually started to deploy OpenStack as well as those that are contemplating OpenStack in the future.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016

componenttext: And we'll go next to Brian white with Drexel Hamilton.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about Ansible and what it means in terms of your TAM in terms of what it means strategically with your customers either as a couple announcements around Ansible in the quarter 2.0 and then working with some of
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about Ansible and what it means in terms of your TAM in terms of what it means strategically with your customers either as a couple announcements around Ansible in the quarter 2.0 and then working with some of the big networking vendors like Cisco and Juniper. So maybe it looks like Ansible has a little bit of impact on expenses in fiscal '17, but what does it open up for Red Hat?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Jim. So a couple of things. Ansible I think opens a significant number of opportunities for us. First off, when you start thinking about container management, an idea of microservices where you could have literally hundreds of thousands or m
componenttext: Well, this is Jim. So a couple of things. Ansible I think opens a significant number of opportunities for us. First off, when you start thinking about container management, an idea of microservices where you could have literally hundreds of thousands or millions of microservices, you had to have a way to orchestrate that in an agentless way and some of the leading orchestration tools out there require an agent on every container, which just want scale and a microservices world. So we think as applications move to containerized environment to microservices, it's clearly the best technology. So there's a big opportunity there. I think you rightly notice that it's, not just necessarily compute workloads. How you think about managing network as well. Ansible has been a technology that many of the networking providers are very, very interested in. They're opportunities in IoT. We see it a lot as we do assess with OpenStack. And so it's it into a whole series of areas in the portfolio to obviously early days now, but it has tremendous traction in general in the marketplace of people using the open-source components. And so we feel very, very good that over time, it could be a very mature contributor to Red Hat.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I can just add to that, and I probably shouldn't say this because you're probably going to ask me a bunch of questions after this, but we're very pleased with integration so far. And also, as you imagine with most companies, you look at an acquisition
componenttext: And I can just add to that, and I probably shouldn't say this because you're probably going to ask me a bunch of questions after this, but we're very pleased with integration so far. And also, as you imagine with most companies, you look at an acquisition target and you have a best case and you have on upside case, based on the interest that we're hearing from our sales team as well as our customers, we're looking at more towards the higher end of the range that we had initially anticipated, which is good news this early.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. And if you have to just highlight a couple of competitors, who should we think about in this space?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: In that space? Again, I come back to the large cloud providers that have ways to orchestrate across about. I guess one could say Puppet, but, again, Puppet is less relevant to a whole set of areas that we're focused on. So really, it's hard to say who can
componenttext: In that space? Again, I come back to the large cloud providers that have ways to orchestrate across about. I guess one could say Puppet, but, again, Puppet is less relevant to a whole set of areas that we're focused on. So really, it's hard to say who can compete well against that. That's one of the reasons were so excited about the technology.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Michael Turits with Raymond James.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 questions. One, as cloud becomes a bigger piece, can you talk about whether or not that will have an impact on duration next year and whether or not should impact how we forecast about billings and at least the component of cash flow will be influenced
componenttext: 2 questions. One, as cloud becomes a bigger piece, can you talk about whether or not that will have an impact on duration next year and whether or not should impact how we forecast about billings and at least the component of cash flow will be influenced by them. And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, as you know, I assume you're talking about the public cloud business that we exceeded $100 million run rate business early this year. So as we talked about over the last 2 quarters, that's great revenue for us, but we recognize revenue in arrears
componenttext: Michael, as you know, I assume you're talking about the public cloud business that we exceeded $100 million run rate business early this year. So as we talked about over the last 2 quarters, that's great revenue for us, but we recognize revenue in arrears. So it's not like the subscription that we have on mostly all the other businesses. So therefore, it does affect as you look at the future and the billings and so forth. That number is growing. It's our fastest growing business right now at a fairly rapid rate, which is great. It's great to see for all the reasons, as Jim mentioned earlier. So as that becomes a higher percentage, approximately right now about 5% of our business, as that becomes a higher percentage, yes, it will have an impact as we start looking at billings and I indicated it looks at the future. If you look at this past year, we just did a rough conservative number to say based on the we had about 50 plus million dollars that came in at new business in FY '16 as it came in around half the year and you just look at what that would have been if we were a subscription versus in arrears. It would have added about 100 million dollars plus to the billings number. So again, as that increases, which we do expect to increase this year, it's another factor that I think would be important to consider even though it may not be in the billings number.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then follow-up question was just on Professional Services, which were up about 9% this year and diminished as a percentage of total. Any thoughts on how that works in 2017 given the need to do things like support the PaaS and support OpenStack?
componenttext: Okay. And then follow-up question was just on Professional Services, which were up about 9% this year and diminished as a percentage of total. Any thoughts on how that works in 2017 given the need to do things like support the PaaS and support OpenStack? So do we see higher growth more in line with the rest of the business? How should should we think about that?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So within the guidance that we provided for FY '17, you could probably assume that it's a little above that 9%. So probably in the low double digits, I would probably guesstimate, not to be to precise on a number, but in that 10% to 12% range. And primari
componenttext: So within the guidance that we provided for FY '17, you could probably assume that it's a little above that 9%. So probably in the low double digits, I would probably guesstimate, not to be to precise on a number, but in that 10% to 12% range. And primarily, that goes along with what we were talking about earlier as far as them of investment that we made with customers on PaaS and OpenStack early on as they go through evaluation.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one more note on that. Recognize, that's a blended number, much higher growth rate around the newer product categories, which were obviously trying to enable where we're constrained on people as -- a shrinking business intentionally as we talked
componenttext: And just one more note on that. Recognize, that's a blended number, much higher growth rate around the newer product categories, which were obviously trying to enable where we're constrained on people as -- a shrinking business intentionally as we talked about in the past trying to reduce the amount of at the work we do, that's something we really don't want to compete with our system integrator partners. And so there's a mixed shift going on in that relative growth rate.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think this question maybe for Frank, both really about the cloud. One is you mentioned over $100 million in cloud subscriptions revenues in fiscal '16, up 90%. I wanted to ask you how comfortable you feel that that number can be up at least 50% in fisca
componenttext: I think this question maybe for Frank, both really about the cloud. One is you mentioned over $100 million in cloud subscriptions revenues in fiscal '16, up 90%. I wanted to ask you how comfortable you feel that that number can be up at least 50% in fiscal '17. And then a related question would be how much bring your own license activity are you seeing whereby customers are moving their RHEL subscription arrangements over to AWS and other clouds? I don't think that activity is reflected in the $100 million. Just curious how much of that is happening.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as far as that -- the first part of your question we -- for all the reasons that we've been talking about even moving to 150 certified cloud service providers right now, that number continues to grow especially with the most recent addition of one of t
componenttext: So as far as that -- the first part of your question we -- for all the reasons that we've been talking about even moving to 150 certified cloud service providers right now, that number continues to grow especially with the most recent addition of one of the largest players like Microsoft Azure. We anticipate back with continuing in FY '17. Can't give an exact number, but again, as I've said before, it's one of the largest growing, it will probably be one of the largest growing in FY '17 as well. We also try to be conservative on that at the same time. So as that grows and expands, that could provide us with some potential upside depending upon how it plays out.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: With regard to your second question, on the bring-your-own subscription, we don't have great data on that right now, but people run them where they want. And so we're tracking instances, but at this point it on targeted to give you specifically on the kin
componenttext: With regard to your second question, on the bring-your-own subscription, we don't have great data on that right now, but people run them where they want. And so we're tracking instances, but at this point it on targeted to give you specifically on the kind of bring-your-own subscription side, but it is not in the public cloud numbers, that $100 million.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct. It is not in that $100 million. That's incremental.
componenttext: Yes, correct. It is not in that $100 million. That's incremental.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a question on the constant currency different rev. For about 7 quarters, the deferred revenue balance in total has been growing very consistently around 20% year-over-year constant currency. This quarter dropped off, it looked like about 1
componenttext: I wanted to ask a question on the constant currency different rev. For about 7 quarters, the deferred revenue balance in total has been growing very consistently around 20% year-over-year constant currency. This quarter dropped off, it looked like about 18%. So just a little bit of a degradation, but if you could just talk about some of the factors that were in that. Was cloud a portion of that? Why it didn't maintain that 20%? Or were there other factors as well?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say that cloud was a portion of that. I mean that just goes back to some of the comments I mentioned as one of the first call questions that we had. Some of that relates to -- you said deferred revenue, right?
componenttext: I wouldn't say that cloud was a portion of that. I mean that just goes back to some of the comments I mentioned as one of the first call questions that we had. Some of that relates to -- you said deferred revenue, right?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's pretty much in line with what we talked about as it relates the billing. We had a strong quarter in the fourth quarter. It was modestly down from what we had seen in Q1 to Q3. So we could see some variations in quarter-to-quarter, but nothing substan
componenttext: It's pretty much in line with what we talked about as it relates the billing. We had a strong quarter in the fourth quarter. It was modestly down from what we had seen in Q1 to Q3. So we could see some variations in quarter-to-quarter, but nothing substantial. We're very pleased with how that performed and the other thing I would note as we talked about in part of the prepared remarks is look at the deferred revenue, also look at the off-balance-sheet. And specifically, that was up pretty healthy year-on-year overall and then if you look at the portion that we broke out, which is over the next 12 months, that was up 20%. So I just want to emphasize that that's another strong indicator of how the business can kind of play out over the next year.

componenttext: And I'm just trying to [indiscernible] is the '17 guidance, which is a little stronger than we're thinking. Is there anything in that number exactly the 800 to 820.

componenttext: No, not really. I mean, one of the things that we're pleased with the cash that we've been able to generate is just a continuation of a very good model that generates ongoing cash. So we feel comfortable with the number other was it wouldn't have guided it's a continuation of all the things that then we want to manage as best we can do collections and the DSO that we have as well as how we're spending a multicast. So I think it's a fairly balanced approach that we're taking.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just, Jim, if you look back on the year here, your growth, Linux growth and your growth continues to outstrip your. It is expected with Windows server and I'm wondering what would your point out as some of the key workloads you think you an
componenttext: Okay. And then just, Jim, if you look back on the year here, your growth, Linux growth and your growth continues to outstrip your. It is expected with Windows server and I'm wondering what would your point out as some of the key workloads you think you and clinics were gaining share in and how do you think that trend as we look into '17 and beyond in terms of some of the workloads?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think almost -- well, almost any what you can give a scale out Mode 2 workload is going to be on Linux, not on Windows server. So we obviously win a huge share of kind of what I'll call the scale out stateless kind of workload, number one. And I t
componenttext: Well, I think almost -- well, almost any what you can give a scale out Mode 2 workload is going to be on Linux, not on Windows server. So we obviously win a huge share of kind of what I'll call the scale out stateless kind of workload, number one. And I think that's a key driver. I think just in general, net new workloads, even in Mode 1 world are more likely to move to Linux now. This developer tool chains, skill sets, et cetera were kind of in a significant shift from a Windows type world to a place where developers start first in Linux. So we take something like containers. Containers are in Linux phenomenon. Docker is a Linux only technology at this point. Windows is working on it. So again, any Docker any container workload is going to be on Linux as well. So we always have a lot of momentum on the developer side, which drags through Linux for us.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take that next question from Heather with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take that next question from Heather with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Jim into Google's cloud events, we've seen announcements of customers switching and using multiple clouds. Do you see this trend towards enterprises using multiple clouds and if so, beyond RHEL, like where you best position to bridge those cu
componenttext: Question for Jim into Google's cloud events, we've seen announcements of customers switching and using multiple clouds. Do you see this trend towards enterprises using multiple clouds and if so, beyond RHEL, like where you best position to bridge those customers? Where it be CloudForms and OpenShift or different areas?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Mar 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, again, I think this is where the portfolio across the board and our commitment to run the portfolio across multiple cloud providers plays in really, really well, right? So whether it's our OpenShift kind of Platform-as-a-Service, which will
componenttext: Well, I mean, again, I think this is where the portfolio across the board and our commitment to run the portfolio across multiple cloud providers plays in really, really well, right? So whether it's our OpenShift kind of Platform-as-a-Service, which will run across the major cloud providers, whether it's various components of our middleware offerings. Obviously, any application someone is written that runs on RHEL that no RHEL will run across all those cloud providers, that's the key part of our value proposition, choice, choice, choice. I would say what we're seeing now is enterprises typically pick a cloud and start there because you kind of got to get started and comfortable with it. But enterprise even today that are on one cloud recognize going forward they're going to have to be able to run on multiple clouds just to have some leverage and some choice. And so I think a lot of enterprises running on one cloud today are architecting their applications to ensure that they can run on multiple clouds. And so and again, that has been what we've been saying in the marketplace for the last couple of years. And it would be both our offering. So we'd love to see people using multiple clouds because it helps highlight our offerings.

componenttextpreview: Yes. And just one note. As these clients, as these customers and these relationships get bigger as we talked about having an enterprise especially wanting to pay upfront or even commit to multiple years once you're getting well into 8 figures, just become
componenttext: Yes. And just one note. As these clients, as these customers and these relationships get bigger as we talked about having an enterprise especially wanting to pay upfront or even commit to multiple years once you're getting well into 8 figures, just becomes less because we don't give significant discounts to get people to pay us, right? We have a very high renewal rate. And so we don't want to lower our price just to get people to either commit or pay us upfront. And when the deals for smaller people, we just have to budget in the year and they want to go ahead and do that, but once start customers get bigger and bigger and bigger, they kind of like the pay-as-you-go model, right? And so they're less likely to want to pay as upfront. I wouldn't be surprised to see that in the future. It's obviously customer by customer dependent, but again, as these larger customers get even larger, I think we're more likely to see them wanting to continue when you're at a time versus multiyear.
