headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Red Hat, Inc. Q1 FY '17 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference ov
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Red Hat, Inc. Q1 FY '17 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Tom McCallum, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Elise. Hello, everyone. Welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the first quarter of fiscal 2017. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Frank Calderoni, Executive Vice President Operations and CFO.Our earning
componenttext:
Thank you, Elise. Hello, everyone. Welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the first quarter of fiscal 2017. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Frank Calderoni, Executive Vice President Operations and CFO.
Our earnings press release was issued today after the market closed and may be downloaded from redhat.com on the Investor Relations page. Also on this page, you'll be able to find a copy of today's prepared remarks, a schedule of currency rates and a slide deck with financial highlights and supplemental metrics that include a reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial results. 
During the call, we may make forward-looking statements about our future financial performance and other future events or trends, including guidance for our second fiscal quarter and full fiscal year. These statements are only predictions that are based on what we believe today, and actual results may differ materially. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that could affect our financial results, and the performance of our business and which we discuss in detail in our filings with the SEC, including today's press release and the risk factors and other information contained in our most recently filed Form 10-K and 10-Q. Red Hat assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements we may make on today's call. 
And With that, let me turn it over to Jim.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you joining us on today's call. Transformation and cloud computing are changing the way companies compete in virtually every industry today. Organizations that rapidly embrace agile IT technology are succee
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you joining us on today's call. Transformation and cloud computing are changing the way companies compete in virtually every industry today. Organizations that rapidly embrace agile IT technology are succeeding as industry innovation accelerates around them. With our open source-based technologies, we are helping customers to capture the business benefits associated with this rapid rate of change. Strong adoption of our technologies is evidenced in our financial results where we delivered our highest Q1 total revenue growth rate in U.S. dollars in 3 years, grew both Q1 total revenue and subscription revenue at 18% year-over-year and had strong sales execution that led to a record number of yields over $1 million in the Q1. 
With that overview, let me discuss some of our recent business and technology highlights from the quarter. Starting with OpenShift, our PaaS solution where we made a number of recent announcements. First, our OpenShift common's members crossed 200 organizations from over 40 countries and includes Global 2000 enterprises, ISVs and SaaS providers, system integrator partners and public sector institutions. OpenShift's commons is an community that encourages collaboration, contribution and best practices for open source technologies in PaaS and containers. 
Secondly, announced the next-generation of OpenShift Online that was made available for -- in developer preview this week. OpenShift Online has had over 3 million applications deployed to it and has now been updated to become the industry's first multi-tenant Docker container and Kubernetes powered public cloud platform. And lastly, our OpenShift technology won a Cody award for Best Platform as a Service for second year in a row. This is a prestigious purebreds award presented by the SIIA. OpenShift also received InfoWorld's 2016 technology of the year earlier in the year, for a second time. 
As a headline sponsor of the OpenStack Summit in Austin, we announced the general availability of 2 new technologies that help bridge the gap between development and operations teams to scale up for cloud computing. First, we launched cloud suite that is designed to offer an integrated hybrid cloud stack with a container application platform, a scalable infrastructure-based on OpenStack and unified management tools. Second and in conjunction with the event, we released the general availability of the latest version of our OpenStack distribution, Red Hat LSP 8, which is based on the OpenStack Community Liberty release. A coengineer solution, Red Hat LSP 8 integrates the foundation of the RHEL with Red Hat's OpenStack technology to perform a production-ready cloud platform. Red Hat's core OpenStack offering now natively includes additional automation for upgrades and updates, infrastructure and more closed management and software-defined storage. 
Our new offerings further solidifies Red Hat's early leadership position in OpenStack. This is exciting given the considerable growth in OpenStack interest level among enterprises, growing levels of customer adoption and further signs of market maturation as more enterprises are moving to live production each quarter. Importantly, we believe that Red Hat LSP is increasingly being recognized as the gold standard for large-scale production OpenStack deployments. We have hundreds of production deployments across the globe and even more proof of concepts are underway, including recent wins with Cambridge University, Patty Power Bet Fair, Fastweb, NASA JPL and proto-bond, the IT services division of Santander Bank. 
A broadening group of enterprise and service provider customers that have deployed Red Hat OpenStack Platform include: Verizon NCA mobile, and a strong ecosystem of industry leaders that around RHEL or Red Hat LSP for a transformative network function virtualization and software defined networking deployments. Of course, Red Hat LSP and cloud suite are just part of a portfolio technologies that customers are deploying to address their digital transformation needs. 
To this point, we had an important new win in Q1 with a global financial services provider, BBVA that speaks to the power and breadth and depth of Red Hat's offerings. This global strategic collaboration with BBVA establishes Red Hat as one of their priority partners. The partnership is designed to focus on business and technical alignment, enabling BBVA to accelerate innovation, manage the growth of financial transactions on digital devices and deliver digital banking services through its global customers. 
Moreover, new IaaS and PaaS-based platforms, utilizing Red Hat technology will enable BBVA to focus on developing applications that can support the heavy demands of those global digital banking services and provide customers with the service and information they want when it is needed. BBVA is a fantastic example of a global enterprise that has turned to an open source-based cloud solution and Red Hat in particular to drive business innovation through technology. We're thrilled to collaborate with them on this journey to transform their business and to help them reach their goal of becoming the world's first truly digital global bank. 
More broadly, we believe that Red Hat is seeing and winning a growing number of large deal opportunities due to the breadth and depth of our stack. As customers move work close to the cloud and develop innovative new applications, they are trained to open source-based solutions to provide them with speed, agility, security, reliability and enterprise features. They're turning to Red Hat and we believe we are well positioned to benefit as organizations invest in private, hybrid and public clouds. 
Today, we announced the acquisition of a JBoss middleware partner, 3scale. 3scale was founded in 2007 with a goal of enabling organizations of all sizes to successfully create, manage and use API in a web-enabled world where API is paramount. It offers a hybrid cloud-based API management solution that separates the cloud management layer from the API gateway, offering customers more flexibility, performance and scale. The company power's more than 700 APIs for more than 500 organizations across many industries, including banker, Johnson Controls, CEDAR, crunch base and the University of California Berkeley. 3scale scale has office in Barcelona and San Francisco, and I want to formally welcome the 3scale associates to Red Hat. 
Next, we will be showcasing more of our portfolio of technologies, customer success stories and customer traction at the Red Hat Summit in San Francisco. Once again, we're expecting strong attendance in our premier user event, which is also one of the largest annual open source events. I hope many of you will be able to join us. In summary, we're excited about our strong start to the fiscal year. We remain optimistic about our outlook for the remainder of the year, as Frank will detail in a moment. As a final note, I want to thank all Red Hat associates around the globe for their innovative ideas and technologies that led Red Hat to being recognized by ST Times as a top 10 influencer in 2016 along with companies like Apple, Facebook, Google and Microsoft. ST Times publishes these companies are making their mark on the entire industry and whose work has made a significant impact on what others build, how they build it and ultimately, who uses it. 
With that let me turn the call over to Frank

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. We are seeing very good momentum in our business and solid execution. This enabled us to deliver results that exceeded our guidance across a number of metrics. At the same time, we continue to invest in our high-growth application developm
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. We are seeing very good momentum in our business and solid execution. This enabled us to deliver results that exceeded our guidance across a number of metrics. At the same time, we continue to invest in our high-growth application development platforms and emerging technologies, which are responding to our customers needs, to enable cloud computing and digital transformation. 
Let me begin with the financial highlights of our Q1 performance. For a more detailed view of our results and reconciliations of our non-GAAP measures to GAAP, please refer to our press release. I am pleased to announce total revenue of $568 million, above the high end of our guidance and representing growth of 18% in U.S. dollars and in constant currency on a year-on-year basis. In general, currency rate volatility has stabilized to a point where many of our USD and constant currency growth rates are essentially equivalent. So for this quarter, I will keep my prepared remarks focused on our reported U.S. dollar results where appropriate, and you will find a table of constant currency results in our press release. 
Subscription revenue continue to be the largest driver of our growth at $502 million for the quarter, an increase of 18% year-over-year. This renewable revenue stream now constitutes 88% of total revenue, providing a large base for future renewals and up selling opportunities for new technologies. We continue to drive high growth across our technology portfolio. Subscription revenue for infrastructure-related offerings was $403 million, an increase of 14% year-over-year. Our application development-related and emerging technology subscription revenue was $98 million, an increase of 39% year-over-year. Application development-related and emerging technologies revenue was approximately 17% of total revenue, up 260 basis points from the year-ago quarter. 
We are pleased to see that we have reached an annualized run rate of nearly $400 million a year as customers continue to adopt our portfolio of technologies like Middleware, the Red Hat OpenStack platform, OpenShift, cloud management and storage. On a non-GAAP basis, operating income of $124 million grew 9% year-over-year and non-GAAP operating margin was 21.8%. This is consistent with a 22% operating margin direction we provided on our last call, which included the investment in the Ansible acquisition. As a reminder, non-GAAP operating income adjusts for noncash share-based compensation expense, amortization of intangible assets and transaction costs related to business combinations. 
Using our non-GAAP estimated annual effective tax rate it of 27%, non-GAAP diluted earnings per share came to $0.50, consistent with our guidance and up 14% year-over-year. We ended the quarter with cash and investments of approximately $2.1 billion. We returned $66 million to shareholders in the quarter through the repurchase of approximately 900,000 shares of stock. Given our strong cash position, ability to generate meaningful cash flow and firm belief in our long-term prospects for the business, I am pleased to announce a new $1 billion stock repurchase program that will replace our previous $500 million plan. We believe this new plan will contribute further value for our shareholders. 
Total deferred revenue at quarter end was $1.7 billion, an increase of $256 million or 18% over the same quarter a year ago. On a constant currency basis, total deferred revenue was up 17%. The total change in deferred revenue from our cash flow statement, which neutralizes most of the impact of currency fluctuation decreased $46 million compared to the end of 2016. This follows the pattern we've seen historically in Q1. Operating cash flow of $232 [ph] million for the quarter was up 8% year-over-year and was at a record for Q1. Strong collections contributed to these results with FX adjusted days sales outstanding at 56 days, that's down from 59 days in the year-ago quarter. 
In addition, during the first quarter, we made the decision to adopt Accounting Standards Update 2016-09, earlier than required relating to accounting of stock compensation. The impact operating cash flow in Q1 FY '17 was a benefit of $8 million and it was the benefit of $6 million when adjusting Q1 FY '16. In Q2, we currently expect this benefit to be only $1 million. Also, as scheduled with historical adjustments for ASU 2016-09 to FY '16 operating cash flows, can be found in the supplemental data presentation that we provided with this call. 
On a rolling 4-quarter [ph] basis, the billing proxy was $596 million, that's up 16% on a constant currency basis and 13% U.S. dollars year-over-year. The rolling 4 quarters billings proxies calculated by adding revenue plus the change in deferred revenue on a cash flow statement for the last 4 quarters. I will now review the metrics of business momentums and large deals in the quarter. 
Our geography saw a continued growth in bookings. This quarter, 60% of bookings came from the Americas, 21% from EMEA and 19% from Asia Pacific versus a 55-25-20 split in Q1 last year. Although some companies have pointed to geographic weakness, we continue to see strong growth across all our major geographies. In fact, while EMEA's relative contribution to our total bookings was lower than the prior year, it's underlying momentum was strong. In Q1, the EMEA sales team was faced with a smaller number of multi-year deals in its renewable when compared to Q1 of last year. There was a focus on driving significant new business and a higher growth rate in single year bookings. Congratulations to the EMEA team on great execution in Q1 and renewing existing deals and growing a new business. 
The Q1 route to market mix was 78% from the channel, 22% from our direct sales force compared to 75%, 25% [ph] split in Q1 of last year. Our proxy for bookings duration was 21 months, which was in line with historic duration. Within our top largest deals, all of them were $1 million or more dollars and we had record 6 deals in Q1 that were in excess of $5 million and of these [indiscernible] 2 were over $10 million. This was a record first quarter for large deals with 45 deals over $1 million, which was up 50% year-over-year. This traction highlights Red Hat's growing strategic importance in our customers data centers and our talented sales team ability to land and expand our wallet share of IT dollars. Cross-selling was strong with a record-high of 80% of the top 30 deals, including 1 or more components from our group of application development and emerging technologies offerings. 
Mainstream customers in sectors such as health care, industrial and agricultural products and retail over-the-top verticals followed by government and financial services customers. With our renewal business, we once again renewed all of the top 25 deals that we were expecting. The total subscription value of these top 25 renewals was approximately 105% of the prior value. Similar to what we experienced a couple of years ago, we had a -- we had several large U.S. government deals that renewed at approximately 100% of their original values, weighing on this metric in Q1. Excluding these government renewals, the subscription value of our other top renewals was approximately 110%. It's important to note that overall, our government sales team delivered double-digit growth across the federal segment in Q1. 
Now we'd like to turn to guidance. Our outlook assumes current business conditions and the impact of the acquisition of 3scale and foreign exchange. We are reaffirming our full year revenue guidance of $2,380,000,000 to $2,420,000,000, up approximately 18% in U.S. dollars at the high end of the range. We are modestly increasing operating margin to approximately 23% due to a $5 million impact from the 3scale acquisition. We are reaffirming the operating cash flow in a range from $800 million to $820 million. We are also adjusting our target for full year non-GAAP earnings per share to approximately $2.19 to $2.23 per share, assuming a 27% non-GAAP annual effective tax rate, approximately a $1 million to $2 million per quarter forecast for other income and investment related to 3scale, which is approximately $0.03 per share. 
For Q2 specifically, this implies the following outlook: we expect revenue to be in the range of $587 million to $593 million, which is up 18% in U.S. dollars at the high end of the range. We expect non-GAAP operating margin of approximately 22.8% and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.54 per share, which includes a 1 penny impact for the 3scale acquisition in Q2. Consistent with prior practices, I will not forecast quarterly cash flow. But I will note that its important to consider that the AR balances to reflect the quarter over quarter change to cash flow. Also, although payments can fluctuation in the quarter, I would also anticipates AP balances to be approximately flat to slightly up with Q1 balances. 
Overall, we are very pleased with our financial performance in the first quarter and we believe we are off to a very good start for FY '17. We are excited about the company's long-term growth opportunity as we are uniquely positioned to further drive the adoption of open source technologies as IT organizations transition their application development and infrastructure to a hybrid cloud environment. Finally, we look forward to seeing many of you next week in San Francisco for the Red Hat Summit and for our Analyst Day on Thursday, June 30. 
Operator, I would now like to turn it back over to you for the first question.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Mark Murphy with from JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Mark Murphy with from JPMorgan.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Jim, looking back on it, the company has held onto this glide path of a mid-teens revenue growth rate for the past 4 years. And it looks like fiscal '17 is going to mark a fifth year. So it has been a very stable and consistent at an increasing scale.
componenttext: So Jim, looking back on it, the company has held onto this glide path of a mid-teens revenue growth rate for the past 4 years. And it looks like fiscal '17 is going to mark a fifth year. So it has been a very stable and consistent at an increasing scale. I'm wondering what you consider the cloud business and the emerging portfolio that you have, and you look forward to the next few years, do you see the potential to maintain roughly that type of a mid teens glide path? Or if you don't want to comment on that, could you just walk us through what you think would determine whether the next move there is slightly higher slightly lower.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I'd certainly don't want to get into providing any type of a long-term view, so let me just talk about kind of the components and how we think about it, right? RHEL continues to grow in the teens kind of nicely. And the other businesses, even a
componenttext: Yes, sure. I'd certainly don't want to get into providing any type of a long-term view, so let me just talk about kind of the components and how we think about it, right? RHEL continues to grow in the teens kind of nicely. And the other businesses, even as they scale and get pretty large continue to grow in the high 30s to high 40s-ish percent. So the issue is, as these other businesses that continue to grow a lot faster, A, can they continue that momentum? And can RHEL continue to grow in the low double-digits? And if so, at some point, those other businesses will rate the overall growth rate up, not down. I think we feel confident the RHEL can continue to grow double-digit. I think the other businesses, we're confident can continue to grow especially in things like OpenStack and OpenShift and storage continue to scale. And so as we do that, you put that together, I feel pretty good about the weighted average of those, keeping our growth rate where it is or taking it up, not down. I think there's better odds of it accelerating than decelerating. Again, as you start to see the other products become a larger percentage of the total and those are obviously, have a lot faster growth rate.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Scott Zeller with Needham & Company.
componenttext: We'll go next to Scott Zeller with Needham & Company.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your comments on OpenStack adoption earlier, could you give us a sense of how many of those are pilots versus actual production rollouts and revenue impact?
componenttext: Your comments on OpenStack adoption earlier, could you give us a sense of how many of those are pilots versus actual production rollouts and revenue impact?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the ones that I mentioned are actually -- they're actually used in production, right? The pilots, we have a ton of those scaling, and those I did mention, those typically don't have the right to mention gets their pilots. So yes, those are all actua
componenttext: Well, the ones that I mentioned are actually -- they're actually used in production, right? The pilots, we have a ton of those scaling, and those I did mention, those typically don't have the right to mention gets their pilots. So yes, those are all actual deployments that are up and running. In terms of revenue. It's still -- immaterial might be too strong a word, but it's still quite small. Again, if you put something in production, nobody buys $1 million or rarely do you see a $1 million initial deployment of OpenStack. You start -- you put applications on it and you grow with it over time. So the deployments are still, 5 figures, may be 6 figures and they'll scale when the applications go there. So it's still -- this is not having a significant impact on our revenue. But you can kind of start to see the traction that as the application portfolios that are running on the structured growth, we'll see it impacting over the next year or 2.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Kash Rangan from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: At one point you must -- I think we've asked this question in multiple ways, but at what point does OpenStack become material to the overall financial results? And also, one follow-up. As it relates to the cloud service providers, could you give us an upd
componenttext: At one point you must -- I think we've asked this question in multiple ways, but at what point does OpenStack become material to the overall financial results? And also, one follow-up. As it relates to the cloud service providers, could you give us an update on what percentage of the overall infrastructure business do the CCSPs represent and how are they tracking for the rest of the year?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, OpenStack when will it be a material piece of revenue is something I wish I fully knew. We're seeing some nice traction. Again, these are things that take a while. There's a real S-curve and we're still in the growing part of the S-curve. An
componenttext: Well, I mean, OpenStack when will it be a material piece of revenue is something I wish I fully knew. We're seeing some nice traction. Again, these are things that take a while. There's a real S-curve and we're still in the growing part of the S-curve. And when that inflects up, it's something I wish I knew. So we're feeling really, really good about it. If you look at OpenStack Summit, I believe this is nonscientific, but I believe we announced more new customers at OpenStack Summit than everybody else combined. So I mean, we're seeing a nice traction there. It's just that these things have to grow. And we'll -- as we hit that kind of accelerating point, it'll start to make a bigger difference.

componenttext: Cloud service providers. I don't think we're prepared to give an update. I would say is its till by far the fastest growing part of our business. componenttext: Yes, we shared last year that we achieved $100 million run rate in our cloud service provider business. As Jim said, we're excited about the opportunity that we have there. Continuing to add to the 150 public cloud providers that we have as part of the ecosystem. And we'll look to another update at some point as the business continues to evolve to provide some further color on that.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim or Frank, we continue to see strong momentum in your large deals, but your different revenues becoming increasingly more seasonal. Can you talk about the payment terms of these large deals? Are you seeing any compression in payment terms or any change
componenttext: Jim or Frank, we continue to see strong momentum in your large deals, but your different revenues becoming increasingly more seasonal. Can you talk about the payment terms of these large deals? Are you seeing any compression in payment terms or any changes from historical patterns? Just trying to see why we don't see these large deals trying to get the relatively comparable billing outperformance. Any color on that would be helpful.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I touched on about this a little bit in Q4. It used to be when our large deals weren't quite as large as they are now. People often paid up front because they had budget for a project and they had a budget that year and they paid up front. Even thoug
componenttext: Yes. I touched on about this a little bit in Q4. It used to be when our large deals weren't quite as large as they are now. People often paid up front because they had budget for a project and they had a budget that year and they paid up front. Even though for us, we recognize that revenue over time over multiple years. As we've gotten bigger and we've become a larger point park portion of their infrastructure, these structures get really, really big. And as companies get more used to subscription type models, they are becoming more comfortable with the kind of pay as you go model. And so now, they pay upfront, they want a discount. And we have plenty of cash in the bank as Frank talked about. We're not going to do abnormal things to get someone to pay upfront. And so now, we still have multi year commitments, but there are people who are less likely to pay upfront as those deals have gotten bigger and people got more used to pay-as-you-go type models. So I think that's just there -- just those trends worked slightly against people paying the outyear portion.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only other thing that I would add to that is as we see much more content with some of the emerging technology products, those tend to be a shorter duration than some of the RHEL agreements that we've had in the past. So that mix is also a factor i
componenttext: And the only other thing that I would add to that is as we see much more content with some of the emerging technology products, those tend to be a shorter duration than some of the RHEL agreements that we've had in the past. So that mix is also a factor in addition to what Jim mentioned.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Siti Panigrahi with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We'll go next to Siti Panigrahi with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up on Mark's question about Linux growth. I'm wondering, could you talk about some of the factors now influencing Linux growth. And also, Gartner recently talked about in a report that how the Linux caused the enterprises increasing
componenttext: I just want to follow up on Mark's question about Linux growth. I'm wondering, could you talk about some of the factors now influencing Linux growth. And also, Gartner recently talked about in a report that how the Linux caused the enterprises increasing and they talk about how you can reduce the Linux cost at this point. I'm wondering what are you hearing from your customer or in the market about that.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so 2 things. I think the -- we continue to actually have share take from Linux and from Windows. But the majority of the share take that we're seeing is that Linux wins the majority of net new workloads, right? So if you look at something like Hadoo
componenttext: Well, so 2 things. I think the -- we continue to actually have share take from Linux and from Windows. But the majority of the share take that we're seeing is that Linux wins the majority of net new workloads, right? So if you look at something like Hadoop, I think it would be very, very, very rare to find Hadoop workloads that's running on Windows, right? It's 90% Linux. If you look at containers, 100% are on Linux because it's a Linux-native kind of technology. So as you start seeing so many of these new technologies, they're 100% on Linux. So Linux overall are taking share vis-à-vis Windows and UNIX because that's where the new workloads are going. So you wouldn't see within Linux, how is our share doing. And I've not seen a lot of customers that have actually transition from RHEL to free. So we feel very, very good about how we're doing in that environment. Obviously, as these contracts get big, they go up a further level in purchasing. And so we have more negotiation on some of those as you would expect as they get bigger. But we have a very strong value proposition. The one area I would say you see particular pushback would be the developers. Developers are one kind of low friction and they want to be able to try things quickly. And so even LEAP have now have developer subscription that's free, so people can use our -- developers can use our production quality products for free. So again, I think as we go forward as the dollars get bigger, of course, people are going to go through vendor management product to try to get the best possible deal. But so far, we haven't lost anyone. When we talk about our renewals renew, and they renew it more than 100%, so we feel good about how we're doing there.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016

componenttext: Two related questions. The Linux infrastructure decel slightly on both USD and a constant recurring see basis. One, I wanted to find out if they -- if we should be thinking about the $5 million as you guys benefit, I believe in the year-ago quarter and whether that was a bit of a headwind of growth. And secondly, if you could just talk about how pricing is working and AR is working as people move over to cloud, Linux, [indiscernible] positive or negative effect.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Michael, it's Frank. On the first part of your question, yes, the $5 million was an impact, so you do have to take that into consideration. The adjustment that we made for the cloud accounting a year ago in Q1 of FY [ph] '15.
componenttext: So Michael, it's Frank. On the first part of your question, yes, the $5 million was an impact, so you do have to take that into consideration. The adjustment that we made for the cloud accounting a year ago in Q1 of FY [ph] '15.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of overall pricing. So we have 2 components of how we sell on cloud. One, is our Cloud Access program where enterprises who have a subscription can run those in their own data center or on the cloud. So that pricing is basically equivalent wherev
componenttext: In terms of overall pricing. So we have 2 components of how we sell on cloud. One, is our Cloud Access program where enterprises who have a subscription can run those in their own data center or on the cloud. So that pricing is basically equivalent wherever someone decides to run it. Our actual subscriptions sold on cloud, in general, those are smaller number of units. So they have better pricing than our traditional larger enterprise deployments. So overall, it's a net positive given the pretty fast growth in the cloud business.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Michael, I'll take a look at the gross margins there. They've been very consistent over the years, at about 94% for subscription, so it's a good place to start.
componenttext: And Michael, I'll take a look at the gross margins there. They've been very consistent over the years, at about 94% for subscription, so it's a good place to start.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Brent Thill from UBS.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, this year on distribution, are there any change that you see that you're baking on the direct cyber? Any additional tailwinds that you see in terms of some of the partnerships that come on board that be different than what we saw last year?
componenttext: Jim, this year on distribution, are there any change that you see that you're baking on the direct cyber? Any additional tailwinds that you see in terms of some of the partnerships that come on board that be different than what we saw last year?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I do think that we are building greater capability with our partners on OpenStack. As there are 2 things kind of happening on there. It is our product is getting easier to use with each release as the install and management tooling gets bett
componenttext: Well, I mean, I do think that we are building greater capability with our partners on OpenStack. As there are 2 things kind of happening on there. It is our product is getting easier to use with each release as the install and management tooling gets better. And our partners are getting better at it. So as we talked about, we've primarily been supply constrained with OpenStack. I think you will see with our partners a bit of a tailwind this year as they will be more capable of selling and installing that for us. Also, we continue to build out our storage partner ecosystem. And as we do that, storage is -- much of that is a partner-related sale. So yes, I do think you will see some tailwind there. I wouldn't necessarily kind of call it out as a massive shift this year versus last year, but it continues to move in our direction.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to touch on 2 quick ones. One, you mentioned that x those federal deals, your contract renewals would've been at about 110%. I'm just wondering if you could put that in context. You guys have been running 120% or better for a while, what kind of
componenttext: I wanted to touch on 2 quick ones. One, you mentioned that x those federal deals, your contract renewals would've been at about 110%. I'm just wondering if you could put that in context. You guys have been running 120% or better for a while, what kind of what trend are you seeing that might be ticking that lower. I was also wondering if you could share with us a little bit, as you see more and more workloads go to places like AWS, how you think about the share that you guys have of the total Linux market versus the share you have on premise.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Heather, on the first. The reason that we identified the government deals was to kind of give a sense for the impact that they had. And as I said in the earlier comments, we do tend to see that from time to time from some of the government deals side,
componenttext: So Heather, on the first. The reason that we identified the government deals was to kind of give a sense for the impact that they had. And as I said in the earlier comments, we do tend to see that from time to time from some of the government deals side, that's why I wanted to put that aside. As far as the 110%, we can continue to see a very good response from customers as it relates to our emerging technologies. And this year in particular, we're emphasizing that even more, and we've been making much more investment in our sales organization and supporting customers around that. So the 100% that you mentioned in previous quarters were sort of tied to 120. I don't see that as being an issue. It's just something that may be more specific to some of the agreements and the contracts that we had in Q1. We're optimistic as far as the pipeline and the types of transactions and the focus that we have around the emerging technology as we continue throughout FY '17.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Heather and obviously, when you take out the Fed deals, which is particularly heavy in Q1, you take some lumpiness around which deals and what are they. Some people buy that product and therefore, they stay flat and therefore, they get a separate dea
componenttext: Yes, Heather and obviously, when you take out the Fed deals, which is particularly heavy in Q1, you take some lumpiness around which deals and what are they. Some people buy that product and therefore, they stay flat and therefore, they get a separate deal to grow and others, it's kind of a one big thing. So there's nothing in the trend that looks like any change from the past. I feel pretty good about continuing growth in those renewables. Relating to our share on Amazon or on cloud in general. Again, as we talked about in the past. Certainly, if you looked at our overall share, it is lower on cloud than it is on-premise. But tying to tease out how much of that is nature of workload versus something different about the cloud deployment model is one that's a lot harder to break out. When we talk to customers and they talk about moving workload from on-prem to cloud, the RHEL value proposition is really, really strong because of the kind of common technology, common support model. So we feel like our kind of share of production workload on cloud is -- feels like it's as high as our share of production workload on premise. It's harder for us to have quite as much visibility as we don't see all that. In the same way that, that in dev and test environments, people will pay for RHEL typically there. I think that same thing happens on cloud. And so there are more dev and test type workload on cloud. But as we're seeing more production workloads move to cloud, we're seeing continued growth and accelerating kind of our business on the cloud provider. So we feel pretty good that the value proposition holds up. We haven't seen anything or any kind of customers saying, oh, I'm moving to cloud, so I'm not buying RHEL. Our customers as they move to cloud or they're using our stack there as well.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016

componenttext: Okay. I know it's early days with having Ansible in the portfolio, I just wanted to ask about that because automation being cited as an important priority for the last folks that we speak with. Can you just talk, Jim, how adoption levels of Ansible are tracking well to your expectations so far?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think without a doubt, it's well above what our initial expectation. Ansible has really had that inflection point and it's really taking off. If you look at Google web search trends, if you look at the open source, use of adoption, we have talked
componenttext: Well, I think without a doubt, it's well above what our initial expectation. Ansible has really had that inflection point and it's really taking off. If you look at Google web search trends, if you look at the open source, use of adoption, we have talked to customers and we're seeing a tremendous amount of interest around Ansible. It's certainly well beyond what we initially expected at the acquisition. Now again, it's still early days, but it's still -- I would say that it has far exceeded our expectations at this point.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016

componenttext: I'm wondering if I could ask 2 related questions about the performance in the quarter on the revenue front on both geographic and the vertical basis. On the geo front, you mentioned that the bookings mix in the Americas was up. But I see the constant currency growth rate, the revenue growth rate in the Americas decelerated. I'm wondering if you could explain that. And then on the vertical of front. The financials, banks are normally number 1, number 2. I noticed they were more like number 4, number 5 in Q1, I'm wondering if you felt a little more heaviness, sluggishness in the banking vertical in the May quarter.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me start on the top 30 deals. And then Frank, if you want to try to do the mix one. We had a couple of really large -- we had 1 large IoT deal that was a kind of a massive renewal, which I think kind of skewed the results a bit, which is kind of
componenttext: Well, let me start on the top 30 deals. And then Frank, if you want to try to do the mix one. We had a couple of really large -- we had 1 large IoT deal that was a kind of a massive renewal, which I think kind of skewed the results a bit, which is kind of put the other category as kind of the largest category. It's in the transportation industry IoT deal. And so I think that kind of had an impact. Otherwise, I think government is always kind of relatively stronger in Q1, which is just kind of I think that's more normal. Other than that, it kind of looked more normal around financial services kind of stack gone down. But again, I think it was skewed by 1 particularly large IoT deal in transportation.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on your question about the geographic split. As I mentioned earlier, we had good growth across -- I'm just looking at the performance of the Americas and in the Asia Pacific over the last several quarters, and it's been fairly strong and consistent acr
componenttext: So on your question about the geographic split. As I mentioned earlier, we had good growth across -- I'm just looking at the performance of the Americas and in the Asia Pacific over the last several quarters, and it's been fairly strong and consistent across the board. From a constant currency standpoint, the growth rates clearly had been a bit stronger in Europe and Asia Pacific. And we had some weakness, I would say in Lat Am in the last quarter or so that could have had an impact on the overall currency.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I was thinking if you could talk a little bit about how we should think about OpenShift, then the move of developers to the cloud versus a lot of the traction you've had with JBoss over the last few years. Is that at all cannibalistic I guess to beyo
componenttext: Jim, I was thinking if you could talk a little bit about how we should think about OpenShift, then the move of developers to the cloud versus a lot of the traction you've had with JBoss over the last few years. Is that at all cannibalistic I guess to beyond the on-premise middleware world? I guess, you get a lot of questions on that side, just love your perspective on that, how we should be maybe thinking about it.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I mean, recognize the majority of the revenue around OpenShift is still OpenShift on-premise, right? We originally started OpenShift as an online product offering and a lot of our customers didn't said, hey, we actually want this on-prem. And s
componenttext: Yes, sure. I mean, recognize the majority of the revenue around OpenShift is still OpenShift on-premise, right? We originally started OpenShift as an online product offering and a lot of our customers didn't said, hey, we actually want this on-prem. And so that's still be a stronger part of that business. But overall, it's still pretty synergistic and that we now offer all the JBoss services as services on OpenShift. And so once someone is on OpenShift, it actually does help pull through the JBoss services. And then vice versa if you're using the JBoss services and you're looking for a PaaS, it's a natural way to go. So there's some real synergy between the 2. I'm not sure about fully answering your question. If not, next week, we can go through that in a fair amount of detail.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Keith Bachman of Bank of Montréal.
componenttext: We'll go next to Keith Bachman of Bank of Montréal.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your remarks, you indicated that you thought RHEL could sustain teens growth. Could you talk a little bit about how you see containers -- the growth and development containers as you look out impacting a fully grown or fully blown operating system or R
componenttext: In your remarks, you indicated that you thought RHEL could sustain teens growth. Could you talk a little bit about how you see containers -- the growth and development containers as you look out impacting a fully grown or fully blown operating system or RHEL in particular, how do you see the growth containers impacting that growth rate.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we actually see containers as a fairly significant opportunity. Recognize, containers they are a form of virtualization, but what they basically do is slice the operating system between the kernel space and user space, right? So all of the user spac
componenttext: Well, we actually see containers as a fairly significant opportunity. Recognize, containers they are a form of virtualization, but what they basically do is slice the operating system between the kernel space and user space, right? So all of the user space aspect of the operating system are in a container. And the reason we actually see this as a positive driver of our business is first off,l containers in general are 100% Linux. Containers are not -- do not run in Windows, they run in Azure today in -- of Linux running on Azure. So first off, Linux gets a 100% of those today, at some point, I'm sure Microsoft will support it, but my guess is it will be like Hadoop where it's 1% or less of those workload. So first off, we get all of it. And within that, the cost is you have the user space in container then 2 things. First off, you need to make sure that you are life cycle managing that. And so most of the big security vulnerabilities that happen in Linux, the bash bug et cetera, happen in user space. So it becomes extremely important to have an operating system vendor that can push updates into the user space to the container. And Red Hat is particularly good at that. So as containers go into production, as ISVs want to deliver their applications in a container format, unless they want to go into the Linux business and develop their own Linux security response team to patch and push those updates, the role of the Linux gets to be even more important, and so we actually see containers the great opportunity for us to continue to differentiate around A, the kernel space and the user space being consistent so having the same host and technology in container itself. And then secondly, just the ability to lifecycle manage against that. So containers overall are good for Linux because it helps us our overall share versus Windows, and within that, we think we have a definitely differentiated position given our position in the. So that's why we can see continued double-digit growth in general than the LS technology, which includes containers.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard with Citi.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question for Frank, just about the dilution from the acquisition. I guess, it looks like that company may be had 50-ish people based on just kind of [indiscernible] around. I mean when do you guys get to the point where you can absorb that acquisition w
componenttext: A question for Frank, just about the dilution from the acquisition. I guess, it looks like that company may be had 50-ish people based on just kind of [indiscernible] around. I mean when do you guys get to the point where you can absorb that acquisition without having to revise guidance for the year in sort of in terms of tradeoffs with your own hiring plans that you might have internally.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Walter, the -- we were really looking at 2 acquisitions like the Ansible we talked about in the last part of last year and then 3scale today. We are, as I talked about before, if I step back with the acquisition and I look at the investment portfolio,
componenttext: So Walter, the -- we were really looking at 2 acquisitions like the Ansible we talked about in the last part of last year and then 3scale today. We are, as I talked about before, if I step back with the acquisition and I look at the investment portfolio, we have needs within the company, related to a lot of the emerging technologies as you continue to start see that ramp from both engineering and then also from a go-to-market perspective. The opportunity we feel is there, the investment required especially we have leadtimes that can go from 12 to 24 months as far as working with customers. We feel the investment to make in those areas is extremely critical for us to drive the growth that Jim referred to earlier that we're looking forward to, not only this year but in the next several years. And so we're also trying to put that in perspective to try to make sure that we can balance it as it relates margin. We know that investors are always interested in looking at the operating margin and how that's performing. So it's difficult when we also want to look at an acquisition especially in the near term. That's not the same we expect this to be dilutive forever. Jim talked about Ansible and how we strongly feel about the performance so far. So as these acquisitions start to show some traction, especially as part of Red Hat, we expect them to start to drive not only upside, but also improving the bottom line. But in the near term, with all the other competing priority that we have in the company and an acquisition or 2 like we have done right now, it's hard to kind of balance that within the overall portfolio. If you step back and look at the margin, I did some analysis earlier and if you go back to FY -- the operating margin, if you look at FY '15, we had about 23% and if you adjust both '16 and '17 looking at how much we're spending for the acquisition of Ansible and 3scale, we're actually look at 22% [ph], in '15, 23.6% [ph], in '16 and if you look at the guidance that we provided for FY '17 adjusted it will be about 23.6 as well. So despite all the needs that we have internally, we're kind of holding the margins and therefore, adding a bit, I think for both of those acquisitions is reasonable.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Edward Maguire with CLSA.
componenttext: We'll go next to Edward Maguire with CLSA.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's encouraging to see the -- of the 3 million applications that are running on OpenShift. But I wanted to ask to what extent that adoption is driving pull through of really the underlying RHEL and Red components of the Platform-as-a-Service.
componenttext: It's encouraging to see the -- of the 3 million applications that are running on OpenShift. But I wanted to ask to what extent that adoption is driving pull through of really the underlying RHEL and Red components of the Platform-as-a-Service.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- it's built on the product that includes RHEL, right? So OpenShift is a product, is a full stack from the hardware up -- from the OS up. So it's pulled through because it's all kind of built into 1 SKU together, so the workload it's running on
componenttext: Well, the -- it's built on the product that includes RHEL, right? So OpenShift is a product, is a full stack from the hardware up -- from the OS up. So it's pulled through because it's all kind of built into 1 SKU together, so the workload it's running on it is kind of our stack. Now obviously, if the online runs on Amazon or Azure or Google, there's infrastructure underneath that. But the rest of the stack is ours and it's just kind priced as kind of 1 SKU that includes those components.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to a John DiFucci with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to a John DiFucci with Jefferies.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, you talked a lot about the recurring subscription revenue. I guess, the question for you or Frank. Is there any -- has there been any change to the revenue renewal rate over the last few years? I'm not sure you used to talk about sort of an 80% renew
componenttext: Jim, you talked a lot about the recurring subscription revenue. I guess, the question for you or Frank. Is there any -- has there been any change to the revenue renewal rate over the last few years? I'm not sure you used to talk about sort of an 80% renewal rate across the entire business and this is, excluding up sells. Is it still around the same rate today? Or with larger deals, has gotten higher?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little better than that now. So the -- there are a couple of issues in measuring that. I actually, we believe it's a fair amount better than that. The piece where we sometimes lose data is our business through OEMs. If somebody buys a server with a
componenttext: It's a little better than that now. So the -- there are a couple of issues in measuring that. I actually, we believe it's a fair amount better than that. The piece where we sometimes lose data is our business through OEMs. If somebody buys a server with a 3 years SKU, runs RHEL for 3 years,l that has RHEL on there, that first one would've been considered not renewed and then the new server would be new business. So if you leave that out and you look at what we have visibility into, our renewal rates has increased pretty consistently over the last several years. How much of that's dynamic a larger deal versus how much of that is we've been focused on it, especially we have a very high renewal rates of larger deals, right? Very high close to 100% for our larger customers. As you go down to some of the smaller customers, it's been lower and we've had more of a focus on that. We worked with partners, we built programs with our distributors, so our renewal rate continues to expand. If your question though, I'd say a lot of that is because of better execution, in terms of just strategic dynamic around that I guess, we get to be a bit more strategic to people, that probably helps as well, but the renewal rate is still in the 80s, but it continues to creep up.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Steven Ashley with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: We'll go next to Steven Ashley with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jason on for Steve, I was just wondering if we could get an update on Rev, the performance of that product. And maybe if you could comment on the pace of Rev's growth versus RHEL growth.
componenttext: This is Jason on for Steve, I was just wondering if we could get an update on Rev, the performance of that product. And maybe if you could comment on the pace of Rev's growth versus RHEL growth.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, well, Rev continues to perform better and better. As we talked about -- as people have started to look and say hey, I'm really interested in OpenStack and then there are a set of customers who look at that and say well, we're actually running
componenttext: Yes. I mean, well, Rev continues to perform better and better. As we talked about -- as people have started to look and say hey, I'm really interested in OpenStack and then there are a set of customers who look at that and say well, we're actually running workloads, and in the end, you work it through and it turns out what they really, really want is a VMware replacement, we've seen the Rev business grow nicely. In terms of growth rate, it looks a lot more like our application development and emerging technologies, like RHEL in terms of growth rates, yet substantially faster than RHEL overall. So yes, that business is doing very nicely.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, I wanted to follow-up on rev, and just want to understand in terms of the top 30 deals, how many of those included Rev? And then, also just understand, what are the prospects actually accelerate the growth rate there? It seems like it hasn't qui
componenttext: Actually, I wanted to follow-up on rev, and just want to understand in terms of the top 30 deals, how many of those included Rev? And then, also just understand, what are the prospects actually accelerate the growth rate there? It seems like it hasn't quite hit the stride that may be expected it to at this point, relative to when you introduced it. But it seems like it's picking up momentum. Is there an inflection point in your mind where rev really kind of takes off?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 22, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, it was in 4 deals of the top 30 deals. I think we'll see -- when we first entered years ago, yes, we thought okay, well, this is a great alternative to VMware. But frankly, a lot of people had other issues to worry about, they're comfortable wi
componenttext: Yes. Well, it was in 4 deals of the top 30 deals. I think we'll see -- when we first entered years ago, yes, we thought okay, well, this is a great alternative to VMware. But frankly, a lot of people had other issues to worry about, they're comfortable with their VMware infrastructure. And so we didn't get the same share take as we've gotten there as we got say in the middleware portfolio where certainly UNIX the Linux. And the majority of the rev that we've seen has been more -- hey, I'm adding net new workloads and I'm going to do that on rev because it's cheaper than the alternative. But we haven't had the normal, I would say kind of rip and replace share take that we have of web screen logic to JBoss or Windows or a Linux to RHEL. The big question, I think we have in all of our minds is, will that change as OpenStack continues to grow when people say, I have a set of workloads that aren't really immutable to OpenStack. Once you have KVM as the underlying hypervisor, and you have a set of management tools that look kind of similar across, that seems to be what's driving incremental rev growth at this point. So yes, I think that, that can kind of pick up nicely and I think that's where we're seeing pretty fast growth in that overall. I think that does hit an inflection point or not, it's generally kind of we're selling it as part of a portfolio, again with our other technologies.
