headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Red Hat, Inc. Q2 FY 2017 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded, and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. It is now my pleasure to turn the conferenc
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Red Hat, Inc. Q2 FY 2017 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, today's call is being recorded, and I will be standing by should you need any assistance. 
It is now my pleasure to turn the conference over to Tom McCallum, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Elise. Hello, everyone. Welcome to Red Hat's Earnings Call for the Second Quarter of Fiscal 2017. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Frank Calderoni, Executive Vice President, Operations, and CFO.Our earn
componenttext:
Thank you, Elise. Hello, everyone. Welcome to Red Hat's Earnings Call for the Second Quarter of Fiscal 2017. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Frank Calderoni, Executive Vice President, Operations, and CFO.
Our earnings press release was issued today after the market closed and may be downloaded from redhat.com on the Investor Relations page. Also on this page, you'll be able to find a copy of today's prepared remarks, a schedule of currency rates and a slide deck with financial highlights and supplemental metrics that along with our earnings press release, include a reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financials.
During the call, we will make forward-looking statements about our future financial performance and other future events or trends, including guidance for our third fiscal quarter and full fiscal year. These statements are only predictions that are based on what we believe today, and actual results may differ materially. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that could affect our financial results and the performance of our business and which we discuss in detail in our filings with the SEC, including today's earnings press release and the risk factors and other information contained in our most recently filed Form 10-K and Form 10-Q. Red Hat assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements we may make on today's call.
And with that, let me turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you joining us on today's call. We continued business momentum in Q2, which showed -- with strong revenues above our guidance, driven mainly by subscription revenue, which grew 20% in U.S. dollars. This
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you joining us on today's call. We continued business momentum in Q2, which showed -- with strong revenues above our guidance, driven mainly by subscription revenue, which grew 20% in U.S. dollars. This growth was highlighted by 18% growth for our infrastructure offerings, combined with 33% growth for our application development and emerging technologies. 
Our growth was driven in part by expanding our footprint with customers as we closed a record number of deals over $1 million, up approximately 60% year-over-year. Digital transformation and hybrid cloud computing are changing how applications are built, deployed and managed. As organizations adopt agile application development technologies, such as Linux Containers, they are increasingly relying on Red Hat as their strategic partner to monetize -- to modernize their infrastructure and application development platforms. These trends are reflected in our results. 
With that overview, let me discuss some of the recent business and technology highlights for the quarter. At the beginning of Q2, we held our largest ever Red Hat Summit event, with record attendance, up 10% compared to last year. We showcased our portfolio of technologies, customer success stories and partner traction. Let me summarize some of the exciting announcements from the Summit.
Starting with Linux Containers. This year's summit was all about containers. We extended our offerings around OpenShift, which is our container platform, so it is now available across a number of environments. We have OpenShift for developers that can be run on laptops. We have OpenShift for the lab that enables developers to move easily from dev to test. And as applications move into production, we have OpenShift Enterprise. We cover the life cycle of an application with our end-to-end platform, and because these 3 offerings are the same platform, customers will not have to retool their platform to build their container applications. 
The developer experience is designed to be similar from the day they first start writing code for their new application until they provision and manage a mission-critical application for live deployment. 
In Middleware, we released JBoss EAP 7. It has been optimized for hybrid cloud computing environments, and when deployed with Red Hat OpenShift, EAP 7 offers the benefits of containers, load balancing, elastic scaling, health monitoring and the ability to deploy containers directly, which can improve the developer experience and productivity. 
In addition, JBoss EAP with OpenShift contributes to a more architecturally efficient DevOps environment since overlapping features are no longer needed. We also announced the general availability of Red Hat JBoss Data Grid 7. The latest version of Red Hat's in-memory data management technology introduces enhancements to help organizations generate insights for continuous business optimization through real-time data analytics, contributing to greater agility and competitiveness. 
In our storage portfolio, we announced Red Hat Ceph Storage 2 with several new capabilities that enhance support for object storage workloads and promote greater ease-of-use. This latest version of the product is the most significant update to Red Hat Ceph Storage to date. We believe our customers will find Red Hat Ceph Storage 2 to be a fully featured, technically advanced storage platform that's easier to use and helps them manage vast quantities of data. 
On the management side, we continue to evolve our offerings with new versions of Ansible Tower 3 and Red Hat Insights launched at Summit. Following up on these announcements, we recently launched Red Hat Virtualization 4, which introduces new and enhanced capabilities around performance, management and automation. RHEV 4 introduces support for OpenStack and Linux Containers to run with enhanced security and reliability. This type of leadership in innovation enabled us to be recognized as the only company included in the Visionaries quadrant of Gartner's Magic Quadrant for x86 Server Virtualization Infrastructure. We believe that this position reinforces our continued innovation, momentum and strong vision for an open, high-performance virtualization alternative.
Rounding out our portfolio of hybrid cloud solutions, we recently introduced OpenStack Platform 9 or OSP 9. It builds on the proven, trusted foundation of Red Hat Enterprise Linux to provide critical dependencies needed in production OpenStack environments. It is a production-ready OpenStack distribution that offers automated upgrade and update paths for mission-critical operations. OSP 9 brings significant updates to the mainstream -- the Mikata version of the -- of OpenStack. Overall, OSP, backed by a robust ecosystem of partners, including Cisco, Dell, Intel and Lenovo, has emerged as a proven solution to power private clouds across hundreds of customers worldwide, such as BBVA, Cambridge University, FICO, NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Paddy Power Betfair, Santander Bank and Verizon. 
In summary, we are pleased to close out the first half of our fiscal year on a strong note, and we're even more excited about Red Hat's future. We believe that Red Hat is uniquely positioned to benefit from long-term secular changes in IT infrastructure that companies are deploying to support their businesses. We are delivering innovation and enterprise capabilities to the open source marketplace at a rapid pace. In doing so, we continue to build out a portfolio of technologies and capabilities to enable our customers to enjoy the benefits associated with the digital transformation and hybrid cloud computing as they develop their applications. 
We remain optimistic about our outlook for the remainder of the year, as Frank will detail in a moment. As a final note, this past quarter, Linux celebrated its 25th year since its creation. And I want to recognize and thank the creative energy of the open-source community, including the many Red Hat associates that have continued to drive innovation and helped to build Red Hat. Collaboration with the open-source community and the focused efforts of associates around the globe has enabled Red Hat to be recognized once again as one of Forbes Most Innovative Companies. This is a key reason that Red Hat is trusted as one of the strategic technology providers to enterprises around the world. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Our business continues to demonstrate good momentum and strong execution by our global teams. We exceeded our guidance across a number of metrics in Q2. The strength in our subscription revenue continued to drive our results, highlighted b
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. Our business continues to demonstrate good momentum and strong execution by our global teams. We exceeded our guidance across a number of metrics in Q2. The strength in our subscription revenue continued to drive our results, highlighted by accelerated revenue growth in our core infrastructure offerings and high revenue growth in our portfolio of new technology that enable hybrid cloud computing and digital transformation.
Let me begin with the financial highlights of our Q2 performance. For a more detailed view of our results and for reconciliations of our non-GAAP measures to GAAP, please refer to our earnings press release and the slide deck with financial highlights and supplemental metrics. These non-GAAP disclosures should not be used as a substitute for our GAAP results or rather read in conjunction with our GAAP results.
Similar to Q1, currency rate volatility has stabilized year-over-year, for example, on a constant-currency basis, using rates from Q2 last year, total revenue growth would've been 18% or approximately 70 basis points lower. I will keep my prepared remarks focused on our reported USD results where appropriate, and you will find a table of constant-currency results in our press release. 
I'm pleased to announce total revenue of $600 million, above the high end of our guidance and representing growth of 19% in U.S. dollars. This result was driven mainly by modestly better-than-expected sales performance and additional revenue related to our education and compliance program.
As I discussed, subscription revenue continued to be the largest driver of our growth as $531 million for the quarter, an increase of 20% year-over-year. This mainly renewable revenue stream now constitutes 89% of total revenue, providing us with a large base to expand our relationships with our customers. 
We continue to drive high growth across our technology portfolio. Subscription revenue for our infrastructure-related offerings was $427 million, an increase of 18% year-over-year. Our application development-related and emerging technologies subscription revenue was $104 million, an increase of 33% year-over-year. Application development-related and emerging technologies revenue was approximately 17% of total revenue, and that's up 180 basis points from a year-ago quarter.
On a non-GAAP basis, operating income of $137 million grew 11% year-over-year, and non-GAAP operating margin was 22.8%, which is consistent with the operating margin direction we provided on our last call, and up 100 basis points from Q1. As a reminder, non-GAAP operating income adjusts for noncash share-based compensation expense, amortization of intangible assets and transaction costs related to business combinations.
Using our estimated annual effective tax rate of 27%, non-GAAP diluted earnings per share came to $0.55, which was $0.01 above our guidance and up 17% year-over-year. We ended the quarter with cash and investments of approximately $2 billion. We returned $127 million to shareholders in the quarter through the repurchase of approximately 1.8 million shares of stock. This is one of our largest direct repurchases in the quarter and reflects our commitment to return value to shareholders with our recent $1 billion repurchase authorization.
Total deferred revenue at quarter end was $1.7 billion, an increase of $267 million or 19% over the same quarter a year ago. On a constant-currency basis, total deferred revenue was up 17%. Operating cash flow was $97 million for the quarter compared to $123 million in the year-ago quarter. Comparing the 2 quarters, our days sales outstanding was 1 day better than Q2 last year at 57 days on an FX-adjusted basis. However, the majority of our strong second quarter billings performance occurred in the last month of the quarter and contributed to a sequential increase of $31 million in our accounts receivable balance.
In addition, our first-half investments in our hybrid cloud technologies and sales capabilities led to an increase in expense of $20 million year-over-year. Some of this expense led to a higher use of operating cash flow. Although predicting the timing of cash inflows and outflows can be a difficult ability on a quarterly basis, we remain comfortable with our full year cash flow guidance, which includes our assumption of higher revenue, seasonally higher billings, increased non-GAAP operating margin for the remainder of the fiscal year and the slightly different linearity of cash flows.
The rolling 4-quarters billings proxy is calculated by adding revenue plus the change in deferred revenue on a cash flow statement for the last 4 quarters. On a rolling 4-quarters basis, the billings proxy was $620 million, up 17% on a constant-currency basis and 15% U.S. dollars year-over-year.
I will now review the metrics for the business momentum and large deals in the quarter. All of our geographies saw double-digit growth in bookings, with particular strength in EMEA and Asia Pacific. This quarter, 57% of bookings came from the Americas, 24% from EMEA, and 19% from Asia Pacific. And this is versus a 60/22/18 split in Q2 of last year. 
The Q2 route-to-market mix was 81% from the channel and 19% from our direct sales force, and this compares to a 75/25 split in Q2 of last year. This is the large portion of channel business in a quarter and reflects channel strength across our major geographies.
Our proxy for bookings duration was 22 months, and that's up approximately 1.5 months from Q2 of last year, and that's driven in part by growth in deals over $1 million. In fact, this was a record second quarter for large deals, with 55 deals over $1 million, which was up 60% year-over-year. This traction highlights Red Hat's growing strategic importance in our customers' data centers and our talented sales teams' ability to land and expand our wallet share of IT dollars.
Looking sequentially at our top 30 largest deal metrics, all of the deals were $1 million or more, and 5 of those deals were in excess of $5 million. Cross-selling was strong, with over 70% of the top 30 deals, including one or more components from one group of application development and emerging technologies offerings.
Financial services and government were our top verticals in Q2. Within our top 25 renewal business, we renewed 23 of the top 25 deals that we were expecting. The total subscription value of these top 25 renewals was approximately 105% of the prior value. 1 of the 2 deals that did not renew was related to a government agency project that was canceled. This agency continues to rely on Red Hat technologies, including a 6-figure deal that closed in the quarter. The second deal that did not renew was lost to an on-premise legacy Linux distribution. We are still engaged with this customer in other areas of their business. And as with a few times in the past this has happened, we are optimistic that we can win back the lost portion over time as a result of our award-winning service and innovation.
Substituting these 2 deals within the next 2 deals up for renewal, the revised top 25 deals that did renew were approximately 115% higher than the prior year value. Given the growth in million-dollar deals this quarter, we are clearly driving larger wallet share by taking a number of 6-figure deals and expanding them to million-dollar-plus renewals.
Now I'd like to turn to the guidance. Our outlook assumes current business conditions and foreign exchange. We are raising our full year revenue guidance to $2,415,000,000 to $2.435 billion, which is up approximately $15 million in U.S. dollars at the high end of the previous range. We are reaffirming our non-GAAP operating margin at approximately 23%. We are reaffirming the operating cash flow in the range from $800 million to $820 million. Given our revenue guidance, our target for full year non-GAAP earnings per share is estimated to be approximately $2.23 to $2.25 per share, assuming a 27% annual effective tax rate, approximately $1 million to $2 million per quarter forecast for other income.
For Q3 specifically, this implies the following outlook: we expect revenue to be in the range of $613 million to $623 million, which is up 19% in U.S. dollars at the high end of the range or 18% in constant currency. We expect non-GAAP operating margin of approximately 23.3% and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.58. Consistent with prior practices, I will not forecast quarterly cash flow given the variability of cash inflows and outflows.
Overall, we are very pleased with our financial performance in the first half of FY '17. We continue to see strong global demand for our hybrid cloud technology as organizations continue to modernize their infrastructure platform and their application development platform. 
Operator, I would now like to turn the call back to you for the first question.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Raimo Lenschow with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Raimo Lenschow with Barclays.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe more higher-level questions for Jim. Jim, if you think about your customers, there's a lot of rethinking going on and people are moving more and more or want to move towards more consumption-based models, you have some of that in your cloud offering
componenttext: Maybe more higher-level questions for Jim. Jim, if you think about your customers, there's a lot of rethinking going on and people are moving more and more or want to move towards more consumption-based models, you have some of that in your cloud offering. Can you talk a little bit about your thinking of about Red Hat going forward and the way you can also engage the customers in this new world?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, for starters, the good news for us is we really are pretty heavily in a consumption-based model with the subscription, the way we have it today. And we make it very easy with Cloud Access, where people use those subscriptions on-premise or across pu
componenttext: Well, for starters, the good news for us is we really are pretty heavily in a consumption-based model with the subscription, the way we have it today. And we make it very easy with Cloud Access, where people use those subscriptions on-premise or across public cloud. And so we really already have a pretty good hybrid cloud mode. You're right in that we have some customers are coming to us and asking for a true consumption model, kind of pay-as-you-go, and we're working through the details. I'm actually encouraged. The very large customers that we've talked to about that said -- will even say, we recognize that will cost us more than we are paying you today because we're not committing to volumes. But we still think that, that flexibility is worth it for us. And so we're in active discussions with a number of customers as we work out exactly what that model is. But overall, we feel pretty good that, that's going to help our price points.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mark Murphy with JPMorgan.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats on a fantastic quarter. We noticed there's quite a bit of acceleration. So you have acceleration in the revenue growth, the acceleration in the EPS growth, acceleration in the billings growth, et cetera. But I wanted to ask you specifically just
componenttext: Congrats on a fantastic quarter. We noticed there's quite a bit of acceleration. So you have acceleration in the revenue growth, the acceleration in the EPS growth, acceleration in the billings growth, et cetera. But I wanted to ask you specifically just about the acceleration and the upside in the subscription revenue. It's a little unusual to see that much upside in that line. And so, Jim, I'm curious if the public cloud adoption through Azure and AWS and all of the other public clouds is playing a larger role in that. Because we had heard some very strong feedback on the adoption and uptake in that specific area. And as kind of a part B, is the transition from the test and dev activity to the production environments kind of giving you a larger opportunity set there?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I certainly think -- if you look 2 years ago, our relative share on public cloud was a bit lower because there's a lot of dev and test. As enterprises look to move their application portfolio of kind of production workloads, that certainly help
componenttext: Yes, well, I certainly think -- if you look 2 years ago, our relative share on public cloud was a bit lower because there's a lot of dev and test. As enterprises look to move their application portfolio of kind of production workloads, that certainly helps us. I think there's a couple of things that helps us in a hybrid cloud environment. If you look purely on premise, roughly half the workloads run on Windows, right? I mean it's just -- and so -- I don't want to say we're locked out because we do compete for that, but kind of half of traditional workloads we just didn't quite address because they're Windows. As soon as you start thinking about a hybrid cloud world, i.e. workloads that might run on premise or they might run on cloud, that by definition is going to be -- I don't want to say, but it's highly likely 90% of those are going to be on Linux. So that helps us both to see obviously very significant growth on public cloud, but more broadly, I think it helps us with our adoption even of core Linux in kind of hybrid cloud environments, which is both on-premise as well as in public cloud. So the hybrid cloud model and the fact that public clouds are starting to take share of workloads is actually kind of a -- it's a tailwind for our business.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, when -- at the Analyst Day, I showed that model, which we looked at some of the customers that had been moving to the public cloud. And we continue to monitor that data. And through the second quarter, it totally confirms that the large customers th
componenttext: Mark, when -- at the Analyst Day, I showed that model, which we looked at some of the customers that had been moving to the public cloud. And we continue to monitor that data. And through the second quarter, it totally confirms that the large customers that are actually using the public cloud with us are also growing substantially their business on the private side, too. So really enforces the whole hybrid cloud model that we have with our customers and how it's growing. So that's, I think, a good indication, and we support, of the hybrid cloud environment for the majority, if not all of our customers.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michael Turits with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michael Turits with Raymond James.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guys, can you just walk through again some of the mechanics on cash flow and, again, how that miss works in terms of the linearity this quarter? And why doesn't your -- raising those metrics but not the cash flow metrics for the full year?
componenttext: Guys, can you just walk through again some of the mechanics on cash flow and, again, how that miss works in terms of the linearity this quarter? And why doesn't your -- raising those metrics but not the cash flow metrics for the full year?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you look at kind of the dynamics of what we saw in the first half of the year, our constant-currency revenue grew about 18%. This is for the first half of the year. Our constant-currency expenses grew at 22%. And as we talked about in the past
componenttext: Sure. So if you look at kind of the dynamics of what we saw in the first half of the year, our constant-currency revenue grew about 18%. This is for the first half of the year. Our constant-currency expenses grew at 22%. And as we talked about in the past, coming off of the end of last year, our objective for the first half of this year was to front-load a lot of our investments and really focus those investments on application development and emerging technologies. And so throughout the first half, and you can see that with some of our headcount numbers as well, we added probably, in addition, 1,000 employees. So that headcount was up about 25% year-on-year in the first half, primarily in sales, driving capacity to help support future growth around the app dev and emerging technologies. We also delivered strong billings growth, right, 18% for the first half, which I think is a good indication of the business momentum. Now in the second half, so that's pretty much -- if you look at what I just laid out especially with the expense, that had an impact on the cash for the second quarter with the $97 million that we announced. It also -- we mentioned earlier that some of the transactions that we had, especially the larger ones, came in later in the quarter. And so that increased the AR, so there was a lighter amount of collections in the quarter to the magnitude of about $31 million. So that's kind of the dynamics for the first half. If we look at the second half of the year, aligned with the guidance that we just gave, we're expecting our seasonally stronger billings to contribute to cash flow, as you would expect especially in Q4. We're forecasting about 16% constant-currency revenue growth when you look at the second half, based on -- that's at the low end, 16% to kind of 18% range. And we're also forecasting 16% operating expense growth. And that's really driven by -- kind of offset to the amount of investment that we made in the first half of the year. So we're bringing the investment levels down in the back half and pretty much leveraging the investments that we've made, as I said, in the application dev and emerging technologies. So with those dynamics, we feel comfortable with the guidance that we gave, both for the top line for our expense as well as our cash flow, and that cash flow is in that $800 million to $820 million.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I know it's still early, but I'm curious, could you compare Azure to AWS when it was a few quarters in. And I know you said in the past that you think there could be more production workload on Azure, anything stand out to you so far on that particul
componenttext: Jim, I know it's still early, but I'm curious, could you compare Azure to AWS when it was a few quarters in. And I know you said in the past that you think there could be more production workload on Azure, anything stand out to you so far on that particular platform?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's still pretty early days. We have a much better, if you can say, that's maybe not the right approach.  Well, if you look at the number of Fortune 500, if you want to call those big blue chip companies running on Azure, that's where it really started w
componenttext: It's still pretty early days. We have a much better, if you can say, that's maybe not the right approach.  Well, if you look at the number of Fortune 500, if you want to call those big blue chip companies running on Azure, that's where it really started with Azure, where AWS really started off with smaller, kind of mom-and-pop-type shops. So it's clearly large enterprise we're looking to move production workload immediately. I think that's the good news. The bad news is nobody in this production workload's got a lot of experimentation. So we have a great customer list and dramatically expanding usage but off of a tiny, tiny base. But just the nature of both the customers and the workloads, it's much more large enterprises down, I'm going to say, where Azure really started off kind of more small enterprises and just kind of worked its way up.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: AWS.
componenttext: AWS.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, AWS, small enterprises up.
componenttext: I'm sorry, AWS, small enterprises up.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gregg Moskowitz with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gregg Moskowitz with Cowen & Company.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The 60% growth in deals over $1 million is phenomenal. What are the primary factors. I know Jimmy talked about this at a high level, but the primary factors that you think are driving so many customers who previously spent 6 figures with you, to now spend
componenttext: The 60% growth in deals over $1 million is phenomenal. What are the primary factors. I know Jimmy talked about this at a high level, but the primary factors that you think are driving so many customers who previously spent 6 figures with you, to now spend 7 figures. And then also, some investors when they do see large deal growth of this nature, wonder about whether there's been a draining of the pipe, if you will, or some sort of pull forward of activity, so any update that you could provide on your overall pipeline will be helpful as well.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there are several factors that are all coming together. If you look across those deals, we're doing, I think, an even better job of selling the portfolio. So 7 of those, of the top 30 deals had OpenStack in there, 9 had RHEV. Middleware is  really
componenttext: I think there are several factors that are all coming together. If you look across those deals, we're doing, I think, an even better job of selling the portfolio. So 7 of those, of the top 30 deals had OpenStack in there, 9 had RHEV. Middleware is  really reaching a level of maturity where it's growing nicely across kind of a lot of our larger deals. And I think those things are helping, as well as even with core Linux, we're -- I know we talked about where we are in relative adoption but there's what I'll call the late majority, which is just going from using it in components to making it their mainstream operating system. I think especially again that's the tailwind we're getting as those companies prepare to move to cloud or starting to move to cloud, most likely, they're not going to go with Windows, they're going to go with Linux. And so that just accelerates the share of their production applications that are running on Linux. So I really think it's a combination of the product portfolio as well as kind of just changing an architecture to hybrid cloud.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Greg, we just had our customer advisory board meeting last week, and they're adding on some of the points that Jim just mentioned. We heard loud and clear last week as far as these major customers and I think we're seeing now a more extensive number o
componenttext: And Greg, we just had our customer advisory board meeting last week, and they're adding on some of the points that Jim just mentioned. We heard loud and clear last week as far as these major customers and I think we're seeing now a more extensive number of these customers looking to up-sell or up-stend as far as working with our product portfolio. So really emphasizing -- you look at some of the deals, the multiple deals that we have across our portfolio, in RHEV, in OpenStack, CloudForm, OpenShift Storage, they're all adding on, on top of the rail. So that kind of adds to the overall size of the transaction now, but also adds to the ability for us to continue to work with these customers long term.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Steve Ashley with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: We'll go next to Steve Ashley with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd just like to ask a little bit on -- we saw very strong indirect business. We saw a strong EMEA business. I'm assuming the 2 are related. Can we get some color on maybe where the strength was and what you were seeing in those areas?
componenttext: I'd just like to ask a little bit on -- we saw very strong indirect business. We saw a strong EMEA business. I'm assuming the 2 are related. Can we get some color on maybe where the strength was and what you were seeing in those areas?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I mean, [indiscernible], EMEA was particularly strong across the board. We just had some really nice kind of both new wins and expansion nicely. I don't think there's anything particularly systemic about that. I think we had to have a very stro
componenttext: Yes, well, I mean, [indiscernible], EMEA was particularly strong across the board. We just had some really nice kind of both new wins and expansion nicely. I don't think there's anything particularly systemic about that. I think we had to have a very strong quarter there, and we -- the sales team just did a really, really nice job, which was good to see. In terms of channel, some of our larger deals, and particularly in EMEA where the vast majority of our business goes through channels. When it's stronger, you see the channel mix pick up there. And so I think one of the things you're seeing there are some of the larger deals were fulfilled via distribution, which kind of ticked it up. I wouldn't expect it to stay at 81% over the next couple of quarters. Some of that was just some of the larger deals that just happened to fulfill that way.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Nicole Hayashi in for Heather. Jim, M&A has been a part of the reason why margins have been suppressed over the last couple of years. Can you comment on your M&A strategy and if there are any more areas that need to be filled, especially as it per
componenttext: This is Nicole Hayashi in for Heather. Jim, M&A has been a part of the reason why margins have been suppressed over the last couple of years. Can you comment on your M&A strategy and if there are any more areas that need to be filled, especially as it pertains to reaching your $5 billion revenue goal?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start and Frank, you may want to add in as well. So I don't think there's anything we have to fill in. The $5 billion revenue goal that we set out is based on looking at the markets that we are in today and our ability to execute into those. Th
componenttext: Well, I'll start and Frank, you may want to add in as well. So I don't think there's anything we have to fill in. The $5 billion revenue goal that we set out is based on looking at the markets that we are in today and our ability to execute into those. That said, I do think we are going through a shift, not only around hybrid cloud in terms of architecture but also the application architecture that's being driven by containers. And so we will continue to look for ways to continue to build our container platform. So Ansible clearly is a strong standalone automation business. A key driver for that was the need to have an HLS [ph] way to do automation in a microservices world. So we'll continue to do the vast majority via kind of organic but yes, we'll continue to look for technology to help accelerate that vision as we go forward. Again, it's mainly going to be technology type of things, but the $5 billion is not premised on acquisition, it's just us taking share and...

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Nicole, if I can use the opportunity, as we talked about at the Analyst Day, as far as the technology tuck ins as Jim just described, to really just talk about the 2, Ansible and 3scale, I think, it's to give a quick update. If you look at Ansible, we
componenttext: And Nicole, if I can use the opportunity, as we talked about at the Analyst Day, as far as the technology tuck ins as Jim just described, to really just talk about the 2, Ansible and 3scale, I think, it's to give a quick update. If you look at Ansible, we're now coming off on the 1 year anniversary and in that year, we've had major success, I would say. We had growth in all major geographies. We have had a substantial increase in the business since the acquisition. We've seen great alignment. Many companies, as they do acquisitions, struggle as far as the integration. That has been the complete opposite for us, great alignment across Red Hat and the Ansible team globally. And it's been a leading element of our management portfolio in such a short period of time. On the 3scale side, it's fairly new. But in the short period of time, again, the integration is going well. I think we can also see just in the last couple of weeks especially, the importance of API and the capabilities and generally, as far as thinking about technology in the future and how important I think that's going to be. So from that standpoint, I think we made a very strategic deal move with 3scale, and I think it's going to have some major future benefits for the company.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Brent Thill with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to Brent Thill with UBS.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The core growth rate in the business still looks really good. The emerging product portfolio growth rate decelerated and I'm just curious obviously, you're coming off much stronger comps, but was there anything that you saw in the emerging category that s
componenttext: The core growth rate in the business still looks really good. The emerging product portfolio growth rate decelerated and I'm just curious obviously, you're coming off much stronger comps, but was there anything that you saw in the emerging category that stood out this quarter?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we'd like to see it growing a bit faster and I think we have confidence in it growing a bit faster. If you look now, we have over 1,200 customers buying 1 or more of our kind of emerging technologies. We had 3 OpenStack deals alone that were
componenttext: Yes, I think we'd like to see it growing a bit faster and I think we have confidence in it growing a bit faster. If you look now, we have over 1,200 customers buying 1 or more of our kind of emerging technologies. We had 3 OpenStack deals alone that were over $1 million. So I think we're seeing really, really, really good traction there. This quarter just happened when you kind of look through the pipeline, we also had some big RHEL deals, and I won't say they kind of crowded out others but certainly, we have a certain amount of sales capacity out there to drive growth. So I don't see anything systemic that should say that you'll see the deceleration there. We feel really good about the portfolio, the customers and kind of what we're doing.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as I mentioned before, I mean, the emphasis of the investment that we made in the first half of this year is around the app dev and the emerging technologies. And the bigger driver here for us is Middleware, so we do have a focus on Middleware as we t
componenttext: And as I mentioned before, I mean, the emphasis of the investment that we made in the first half of this year is around the app dev and the emerging technologies. And the bigger driver here for us is Middleware, so we do have a focus on Middleware as we think about the back half of the year and going into FY '18.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Keith Bachman with Bank of Montreal.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Keith Bachman with Bank of Montreal.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to ask about the renewal rate. It was the second quarter of what I would characterize as a lower renewal rate at 105%. I know you said there was a deal that would've put it back in the 115% type of range. But, a, how would you expect us to trend
componenttext: I'd like to ask about the renewal rate. It was the second quarter of what I would characterize as a lower renewal rate at 105%. I know you said there was a deal that would've put it back in the 115% type of range. But, a, how would you expect us to trend as we look out? And, b, if you could comment on the renewal rate across a broader set of customers, this is the top 25 renewal rate, could you give some characterization on a larger pool? What's your experience on the renewal rate beyond just the top 25?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. A couple of comments there and in caveat, breaking it out, this is a deal renewal rate, it's not a customer renewal rate. And as we become more multiproduct, that has the potential to skew results one way or another. So as we said, one of the n
componenttext: Well, yes. A couple of comments there and in caveat, breaking it out, this is a deal renewal rate, it's not a customer renewal rate. And as we become more multiproduct, that has the potential to skew results one way or another. So as we said, one of the non-renewals which obviously pulled that rate down was just a government project, which in the end was decommissioned. That same customer did another substantial deal with us in the quarter but again, that was a different deal. So this is a deal metric and so it's a deal renewal rate, not a customer renewal rate. We need to work as we go forward to potentially come up with a better measure for you so you can better gauge the trend around that. What would we say overall is the fact that we grew the number of deals over $1 million by 60%. None of those were net new customers, I don't think. We rarely have a customer start that big, those are all significant 6-figure deals that are renewing at 7 figures. Our general sense is our renewal rates are actually quite robust and we continue to grow our footprint with customers. Again, there's just volatility in that top 25 number.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if you take the 25 to the top 35 that did renew, with the same methodology, was about 120%.
componenttext: And if you take the 25 to the top 35 that did renew, with the same methodology, was about 120%.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Walter Pritchard with Citi.
componenttext: We'll go next to Walter Pritchard with Citi.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing I noted from the commentary is [indiscernible] services not [indiscernible] largest vertical on [indiscernible] and I think last quarter that was not true, and it felt like last quarter was not quite as strong as this quarter. I'm wondering if y
componenttext: One thing I noted from the commentary is [indiscernible] services not [indiscernible] largest vertical on [indiscernible] and I think last quarter that was not true, and it felt like last quarter was not quite as strong as this quarter. I'm wondering if you could talk about how much of the difference in performance between Q1 and Q2 if you look at the financial services and any other comments around just [indiscernible] right now?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I got most of your question. You were breaking up a little bit there. Yes, financial services had a particularly strong quarter this quarter. We've had a number of kind of sizable dose of renewals but just also, some very large deals. Why Q2
componenttext: Yes, I think I got most of your question. You were breaking up a little bit there. Yes, financial services had a particularly strong quarter this quarter. We've had a number of kind of sizable dose of renewals but just also, some very large deals. Why Q2 versus Q1, hard to say. If I had to be a little cynical on that, I would say some of these larger deals take a while and our sales force probably took a breath at the end of Q4 and then started working on some of these large deals and they didn't close until Q2. But as we're seeing, especially a lot of traction around OpenShift in financial services, which is great to see. As you think about a container platform and the need to understand the provenance of the content as you think about the software development lifecycle around that, to think about orchestration, these large, sophisticated customers are really gravitating towards OpenShift. And that was, I think, reflected as well with some of the strength that you saw in financial services. Overall, in macro, I think there's a huge change that we've seen over the last couple of quarters. I think budgets are relatively tight in IT but that's in many ways, good for us as we're seeing that they partner to help carve out costs.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll go next to Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, I had a question. Obviously, the subscription that I remember this quarter was really strong. And maybe just to get back to the question I think Mark was asking earlier, the beat on subscription relative to the past 3 quarters has been way above at
componenttext: Frank, I had a question. Obviously, the subscription that I remember this quarter was really strong. And maybe just to get back to the question I think Mark was asking earlier, the beat on subscription relative to the past 3 quarters has been way above at least what the Street was expecting. So was it -- can we infer that the cloud contribution which obviously doesn't come off your balance sheet was part of the reason for that? I guess, was there something else going on this quarter that had subscription sort of outperform so much more than what we would thought given it's a recurring revenue number? So I'm just trying to get a sense on what changed over the quarter to create upside delta [ph]?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I mentioned, if you look at the overall performance, I'd say there's probably 3 things that contributed to the better performance in the quarter. First, there was the benefit from currency. So that drove -- it's probably in the range of like $3.5
componenttext: Yes, as I mentioned, if you look at the overall performance, I'd say there's probably 3 things that contributed to the better performance in the quarter. First, there was the benefit from currency. So that drove -- it's probably in the range of like $3.5 million. The second is we did see an increase in our education and compliance business in the quarter which was probably more unusual than we've seen before. So that helped it in actually those 2 areas. And then the rest is subscription across the board. There was nothing from a public cloud standpoint that I would hang out there as far as driving that upside.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just a related question. Obviously, the infrastructure product had a really nice quarter from a growth perspective. When we think about infrastructure versus the emerging, should we think about the sort of margin -- I guess, how should we
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just a related question. Obviously, the infrastructure product had a really nice quarter from a growth perspective. When we think about infrastructure versus the emerging, should we think about the sort of margin -- I guess, how should we think about those in terms of margin? Meaning, if infrastructure is doing really well, you'd think that it comes with a higher margin associated with it, given it's a more mature business? But I assume your sales guys can sell either, so maybe thinking about infrastructure accelerating doesn't necessarily pull with the kind of margin upside you would think about normally. Can you just -- I don't know, maybe I'm not thinking about it correctly but I think you understand the point I'm trying to get out.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I step back, if you look at it from a financial standpoint, I mentioned this back at the Analyst Day, our -- it is a more mature business when you look at our infrastructure with the primary piece being RHELs. And therefore, with that, you would exp
componenttext: So if I step back, if you look at it from a financial standpoint, I mentioned this back at the Analyst Day, our -- it is a more mature business when you look at our infrastructure with the primary piece being RHELs. And therefore, with that, you would expect that, that's driving more of the profit and the cash, true. So as that grows at a faster rate, that is contributing more. On the other side, we're making investments to help, as I said before, to grow the portfolio so that we can better balance and think about the growth for the future on the emerging and the app dev. From a sales perspective, we don't encourage or measure the sales team based on whether they sell one or the other from the standpoint of the profitability, I'm on the profitability piece. What they do focus on in the sales organization is looking at the total customer and looking at what the needs of the customer is sustaining that account over a period of time. And again, the objective in all our customers from their side and also from our side is to continue to sell a broader portfolio. So the emphasis on yes, RHEL is important and we do need to continue to sell RHEL, but that helps build the platform for the additional products that we leverage on top of that.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: One other thought. Recognize those are revenue numbers. Obviously, a lot of the effort going in is to sell projects that will then turn into revenue over time. And so recognize, there is a bit of a mismatch. But without a doubt, selling OpenShift to OpenS
componenttext: One other thought. Recognize those are revenue numbers. Obviously, a lot of the effort going in is to sell projects that will then turn into revenue over time. And so recognize, there is a bit of a mismatch. But without a doubt, selling OpenShift to OpenStack is a much longer effort to sell those things and so those are higher costs in the short run, but that's -- recognize the difference between the subscription and the lag on revenues versus the activities we're doing now to sell things for the future.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we've mentioned this before, the emphasis this year, more so and will be again next year, is on the sales team, is to make sure that they're focusing on selling a portfolio and not just selling an operating system. And that has begun to, I think, have
componenttext: And we've mentioned this before, the emphasis this year, more so and will be again next year, is on the sales team, is to make sure that they're focusing on selling a portfolio and not just selling an operating system. And that has begun to, I think, have an impact and will have even more so as we look to the next 6 months or the next 18 months.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only other comment I'd say, if we actually went and told the salespeople maximize bookings and revenue this year, we would grow a lot faster than we're growing now, it would just all be in selling RHEL. Obviously, what we're investing in the long
componenttext: And the only other comment I'd say, if we actually went and told the salespeople maximize bookings and revenue this year, we would grow a lot faster than we're growing now, it would just all be in selling RHEL. Obviously, what we're investing in the long run against another set of products and those are just longer sales cycles. But we're trying to balance driving kind of current results within investing in these new products for the long run.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to John DiFucci with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll go next to John DiFucci with Jefferies.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Howard Ma in for John DiFucci. Your metrics were really strong across the board so I'd like to add my congratulations as well. Operating cash flow, however, was weaker than what I think most of us were expecting, so I wanted to follow up on that.
componenttext: This is Howard Ma in for John DiFucci. Your metrics were really strong across the board so I'd like to add my congratulations as well. Operating cash flow, however, was weaker than what I think most of us were expecting, so I wanted to follow up on that. So you maintain the $800 million to $820 million guidance for the year which that implies that you're going to increase your operating cash flow by about $100 million in the second half versus -- it was flat in the first half. So Frank, I know you don't guide to quarterly cash flow but could you give some color that might help us model the cadence in the back half? For example, like the larger deals that were signed late in the quarter that you mentioned, should we expect the cash receipts to flow in the 3Q? And then on a slightly related note, can you provide an update on CapEx for 2017, given that you're -- the recent announcements to build innovation and engineering labs in Boston?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Howard, as I mentioned before, the dynamics of the second half of the year is clearly less investment on the expense side, right? So we're going to moderate the investment based on the significant investment we made in the first half. So that would red
componenttext: So Howard, as I mentioned before, the dynamics of the second half of the year is clearly less investment on the expense side, right? So we're going to moderate the investment based on the significant investment we made in the first half. So that would reduce the amount of cash disbursement both in Q3 and Q4. And as it relates to the top line and to our collections, as far as the linearity as you would expect, more of that is going to be in Q4. So I wouldn't model as much in Q3. I would actually shift that more towards Q4 which is kind of how -- and I'm not giving specific guidance on the quarter but just if you look at our linearity from a Q3, Q4 more towards the back half of that 6-month timeframe and that's where we'd have more larger transactions generating more of the revenue to help improve the cash position and enable us to get to that $800 million to $820 million.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to emphasize, again I think we had great sales execution but I have to say our people teams probably even executed better. I don't think we intended to hire 25 -- up 25% in the first half of the year, we just did a really good job with closing people
componenttext: Just to emphasize, again I think we had great sales execution but I have to say our people teams probably even executed better. I don't think we intended to hire 25 -- up 25% in the first half of the year, we just did a really good job with closing people and getting people on board. By the end of the year, we will moderate that back to our growth rate that looks more like what we originally projected. And so we did run hot on hiring in the first half of the year and so that will kind of make a difference as we kind of normalize by the end of the year.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last thing, you mentioned about CapEx. So the CapEx number right now for the year is probably in the range of like $60 million to $70 million.
componenttext: And just one last thing, you mentioned about CapEx. So the CapEx number right now for the year is probably in the range of like $60 million to $70 million.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Kash Rangan with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to Kash Rangan with Bank of America.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My computer just crashed, so I'm flying a little blind, so sorry for this. But when I look at the Middleware business, you've had pretty much of an uncontested the last several years, the installed base of the legacy companies. We're also at the point whe
componenttext: My computer just crashed, so I'm flying a little blind, so sorry for this. But when I look at the Middleware business, you've had pretty much of an uncontested the last several years, the installed base of the legacy companies. We're also at the point where Oracle has started to put out PaaS offering. I believe they booked about $450 million in ARR versus 0 literally, a year ago. You got that one development. Curious to get your commentary on how you would view the prospects for growth in your emerging technologies. From a definition, a lot of that is Middleware vis-à-vis the big push that Oracle's making. Also not to discount Salesforce.com, their PaaS-like product, force.com, is now around roughly $1.34 billion business also growing at 30%, 40%. But you didn't have these kind of developments 4 to 5 years back during the JBoss replacement cycle. Curious to get your take on how this changes or does not change your outlook on emerging technologies potentially getting 40% of your revenues. I believe that was the target at the Analyst Day. That's it for me.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I'll start off. I mean, we rarely -- given the type of Middleware we sell and what we're doing, we rarely directly run into force.com which is much more tied around kind of the Salesforce portfolio. Regarding Oracle, we love when anybody rais
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I'll start off. I mean, we rarely -- given the type of Middleware we sell and what we're doing, we rarely directly run into force.com which is much more tied around kind of the Salesforce portfolio. Regarding Oracle, we love when anybody raises up, "Hey, why don't you think about PaaS?" Because when change happens, we win a pretty nice share of that. So the fact that there's more discussion and consideration around PaaS is a really good thing for us. We still remain, in terms of dollar terms, a small share player in Middleware. So anybody, including incumbents who look to make a shift and therefore get people considering alternatives, that's good for us. So the more focus on talk about PaaS broadly ultimately is good for us because it just increases the number of add backs we have to win. So we feel really, really good about where we are. And again, as people think about modern, whether that's PaaS or just more modern types of Middleware microservices, all of that's a net positive for us.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ed Maguire with CLSA.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ed Maguire with CLSA.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to go back to the question about the relative profitability of infrastructure and the app dev and emerging products. As you use an open source development model, I mean, you built a very profitable business around the infrastructure products. But
componenttext: I'd like to go back to the question about the relative profitability of infrastructure and the app dev and emerging products. As you use an open source development model, I mean, you built a very profitable business around the infrastructure products. But as you look at the newer products where you're making investments, is there a point in the maturity of a product or a project where you feel that you can actually let it take its own course where you don't have to invest incremental R&D? And I'm not really talking so much about sales but the incremental investment that you need to make on the product side for the newer emerging products to really become viable and remain really ahead of the curve in terms of being competitive.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, let me take our most mature product, Linux, right? The vast majority of our engineering expense around Linux is the downstream sustaining engineering around our releases. It's not necessarily upstream feature development for the exact reason th
componenttext: Yes, well, let me take our most mature product, Linux, right? The vast majority of our engineering expense around Linux is the downstream sustaining engineering around our releases. It's not necessarily upstream feature development for the exact reason that you mentioned which is the upstream community does a lot of the upstream feature development. We're obviously involved in a number of those components but the majority of our expense is sustaining engineering. We certainly would expect that as we think about the products across the board. Again, coming back to profitability, sales and marketing is a larger share of the expense. So that's one where whenever you have a new product, there's a higher expense associated with that. Well, we've just looked this up structurally against any of our products, at maturity, I don't -- we don't have any reason to believe that any of our products will be less profitable than Linux. And if we look at renewal rates, those are typically similar over time across product lines. I think we look at kind of the relative engineering against that sustaining engineering, it should look similar. So I think at similar levels of maturity, so far, we think the portfolio will look similar. It's just obviously, we're in different stages of maturity across the portfolio.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016

componenttext: Operator, I know we have a few more questions out there but I'm afraid we only have time for one more.

componenttext: Certainly. We'll take our final question from Jason Ader with William Blair.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, this one's for you. At the Analyst Day, you talked about a balanced approach between topline growth and operating margin and that you expect operating margin to rise over time. When do you expect to be ready to give us some specific medium to long-
componenttext: Frank, this one's for you. At the Analyst Day, you talked about a balanced approach between topline growth and operating margin and that you expect operating margin to rise over time. When do you expect to be ready to give us some specific medium to long-term targets on operating margin?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question, Jason. So just reaffirming, yes. Because at the Analyst Day, I talked about the 3 different options. Wanted to go more heavily towards, as Jim was just talking about, operating system or RHEL and that clearly would have a better leverage mo
componenttext: Good question, Jason. So just reaffirming, yes. Because at the Analyst Day, I talked about the 3 different options. Wanted to go more heavily towards, as Jim was just talking about, operating system or RHEL and that clearly would have a better leverage model in the short term. The other extreme would go more heavily toward emerging markets. I think that would accelerate the growth but cause a margin deterioration in the short-term. We are going with a balanced approach. This year, as I've just mentioned, it's to invest in the first half of the year. Clearly if you look at the margin profile, first half of this year versus the second half of this year, you'll start to see an improvement in the margin in the back half of the year. I think that's pretty much the dynamics of how we're making the investment. As we continue to continue to get momentum on the, let's say, the app dev and the emerging technology products as we go into '18, I think that will allow us a better view of where we think to what extent we really think we can get potentially, some slight margin improvement. So I would say we want to close out the back half of the year with the guidance that we just gave. We're in the midst right now of already starting our planning for re-upping the next couple of years. And I think as we get into the beginning of next year, I think we'll have a better view of what that model may look like over a period of years, and we'll be more than happy to share that. And that's pretty much the takeaway coming off of a lot of conversations that many of you and I and Tom had, following the Analyst Day. So we're working on that as far as our planning and we'll bring that forward when we think about the start of the new year.

componenttext: Operator, I'm afraid this ends our call. I want to thank everybody for joining us today. We look forward to catching up with you over the next several weeks. We'll be on the road and we'll be at several conferences later in the quarter. So thank you very much, everybody.
