headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Red Hat, Inc. Q3 Fiscal Year 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn today's conference over to Tom McCallum, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, si
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to today's Red Hat, Inc. Q3 Fiscal Year 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn today's conference over to Tom McCallum, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lynne. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the third quarter of fiscal '17. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Frank Calderoni, Executive Vice President, Operations and CFO.Our ear
componenttext:
Thank you, Lynne. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's earnings call for the third quarter of fiscal '17. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Frank Calderoni, Executive Vice President, Operations and CFO.
Our earnings press release was issued today after the market closed and may be downloaded from redhat.com on the Investor Relations page. Also on this page, you'll be able to find a copy of today's prepared remarks, a schedule of currency rates and a slide deck with financial highlights and supplemental metrics that, along with our earnings press release, include a reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP financial results.
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements about our future financial performance and other future events or trends, including guidance for the fourth quarter and the full fiscal year. These statements are only predictions that are based on what we believe today, and results may differ materially. These forward-looking statements are subject to the risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that could affect our financial results and performance of our business and which we discuss in detail in our filings with the SEC, including today's earnings press release and the risk factors and other information contained in our most recently filed Form 10-K and Form 10-Q. Red Hat assumes no obligation to update any of these forward-looking statements we may make on today's call.
And with that, let me turn the call over to Jim.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to everyone joining us on today's call.In Q3, solid execution allowed us to continue to deliver double-digit growth in a number of our financial metrics, including revenue, non-GAAP operating income and non-GAAP
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to everyone joining us on today's call.
In Q3, solid execution allowed us to continue to deliver double-digit growth in a number of our financial metrics, including revenue, non-GAAP operating income and non-GAAP EPS. 
Some key highlights of the quarter include: strong demand for our cloud-enabling technologies, which is reflected in the 32% constant currency growth in our application development-related and other emerging technologies revenue; our continuing customer traction is evident in our top 25 renewals that were up for renewal this quarter. All 25 renewed, and they did so at more than 120% of their prior annual commitment. As Frank will describe, we closed many large deals including some of the largest deals in Red Hat's history, with strong cross-selling and longer-term commitments from our customers.
Our customers are increasingly adopting the cloud as part of their overall IT strategy and are using Red Hat as a partner. We see customers deploying our cloud-enabling technologies both on-premise and in the public cloud. This group of hybrid cloud customers is growing revenue in the aggregate faster than customers that have not yet embraced these technologies. In fact in Q3, we added hundreds of customer wins with products from our hybrid cloud portfolio, including several OpenStack deals that were over $1 million. Also of note, we closed our second OpenShift deal over $10 million and another OpenShift deal over $5 million. In spite of the many positives in the quarter, we faced a few challenges that tempered the growth of some of the items in our reported results.
First, some sizable November deals in the U.S. federal space have taken longer than initially expected to close, though we expect them to ultimately move forward in the fourth quarter. In addition, similar to the first half of the fiscal year, we were able to secure large multiyear commitments from customers. However, as these deals continue to get larger, sales activity was again more concentrated in the last month of the quarter. And in this quarter, there was a lower level of customers paying upfront for their multiyear deals.
We're adjusting our revenue and cash flow outlook for the year based on these factors, but it's important to note that we continue to expect full year total revenue growth of approximately 17%, with subscription revenue, which is renewable, growing even faster. We are reaffirming our operating margin for the full year of 23%, and we are forecasting cash flow in Q4 up 22% to approximately 28% from Q4 last year based on the confidence of our outlook. 
Importantly, for the long run, we remain confident in our competitive position and our ability to drive future growth. In fact, given our visibility into our pipeline and what has already closed to date, we are confident that we will see a re-acceleration of billings in Q4 into the mid-teens growth rate range and we will end the year with a strong total backlog. 
Before turning the call over to Frank to discuss the details of the quarter and our outlook, let me provide some additional business highlights for the quarter. We continue to see momentum with customers and community around our cloud-enabling technologies, including OpenStack, OpenShift, CloudForm and related offerings that our customers are using to build hybrid clouds. Within our top 30 deals, 7 included Red Hat OpenStack platform, 5 included OpenShift and 5 included storage.
Starting with an OpenStack customer win. Swisscom has deployed Red Hat OpenStack platform and Red Hat virtualization to build their newest technology platform providing the flexibility needed to support ongoing innovation and development across its own organization as well as its customer base. We continue to improve scalability and usability of OpenStack with our recent release of Red Hat OSP 10. Based on the upstream Newton release, OSP 10 drives new features that increase system-wide scalability, ease infrastructure management and improve orchestration while also enhancing network performance and platform security. A new 5-year life cycle support offering for Red Hat OSP 10 can help customers achieve the long-term stability required for mission-critical operations.
We also announced the broad alliance with Ericsson to deliver fully open source and production-ready cloud infrastructure, spanning OpenStack, containers, NFV, SDN and SDI. Through the collaboration, we plan to work together to certify Ericsson's platform and portfolio of solutions.
Red Hat 3scale API management platform was positioned in the leaders quadrant of Gartner's October 16 Full Life Cycle API Management Magic Quadrant. Red Hat 3scale API management platform complements our existing application development related and other emerging technologies and strengthens our ability to help simplify and accelerate customers' digital transformation initiatives.
In our storage portfolio, Red Hat Ceph and Gluster storage were posed positioned in the Visionaries quadrant of Gartner's October 16 Distributed File Systems and Object Storage Magic Quadrant. Red Hat Ceph and Red Hat Gluster storage are both highly agile solutions that are built to handle different types of demanding workloads.
Before my final remarks, I'd like to talk about the leadership transition at the CFO level. Effective in late January, Frank will be resigning to join another company as its CEO. Frank has been able to accomplish a great deal to help advance and scale our enterprise, as we continue to experience significant growth. 
I'm grateful that Frank has agreed to stay on until late January and assist with the transition as needed. Upon his resignation, Eric Shander, Vice President, Finance and Accounting, and our Principal Accounting Officer, will assume the role of acting CFO. Eric will bring a rich and solid experience base to this role from his work at Red Hat and almost 25 years of experience at IBM and Lenovo. 
Frank, I've really enjoyed getting to know you and working side by side with you. You'll be greatly missed, and I wish you nothing but success in your new role. You're a talented business leader and executive, and you've left us stronger and well positioned to address the opportunities before us. Thank you, Frank.
In summary, we continue to be pleased with our progress in delivering on our mission to work with communities, customers and partners to create better technology the open source way. I want to thank all Red Hat associates for their continued focus on the success of our customers. I'm confident that this team will continue to deliver against our hybrid cloud growth strategy.
With that, let me turn the call over to Frank.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. I would also like to thank everyone at Red Hat, including my teams within finance, accounting, operation, IT and global workforce solutions. These are some of the best people I've ever worked with, and I'm very grateful to have gotten to k
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. I would also like to thank everyone at Red Hat, including my teams within finance, accounting, operation, IT and global workforce solutions. These are some of the best people I've ever worked with, and I'm very grateful to have gotten to know each and every one of you. I received a compelling opportunity to be a CEO at another company, and I couldn't turn it down. However, I have thoroughly enjoyed my time as CFO of Red Hat, and I'm confident this company will have continued success.
Let me begin with a summary of our Q3 performance. Q3 was driven by strong renewals in our large deals, cross selling of our cloud-enabling technologies and lengthening of customer commitments to Red Hat. This sales traction is reflected in our deals greater than $1 million, which are up 20% year-over-year. This is also a reflection of our strategic position with customers as they look to deploy in the hybrid cloud environments using our technologies for years to come.
As Jim noted earlier, the quarter did come with a couple of challenges that affected our metrics. First, we saw a few deals in the federal space that didn't close on the time frame we expected. We believe the proximity of our quarter to the continuing resolution legislation relating to the federal budget was a factor. The continuing resolution legislation has been signed, and we do expect them to move forward in the fourth quarter.
Second, we closed several large multiyear deals, including 2 deals over $20 million, which did not build beyond the first year. As we have stated in the past, customers' desire to pay beyond 1 year can fluctuate and it has an impact on the long-term portion of our billings proxy when this occur. In Q2, we saw strong growth in our billings proxy due in part to more customers paying upfront for their multiyear contracts, whereas strength in multiyear contracts during Q3 continued more to growth in the backlog.
Third, as Jim noted, we saw our sales activity more concentrated in the last month of the quarter versus our historic norm, similar to the second quarter. We are focusing on improving -- making improvements in linearity, and we believe similar linearity could occur in Q4 from a forecasting perspective. As we build our FY '18 plan, we plan to drive better quarterly linearity.
Finally, foreign exchange volatility negatively impacted our Q3 revenue by more than $3 million, and our previously implied guidance for Q4 by $16 million due to the fact that the dollar has strengthened against some of our major currencies since we provided our guidance back in September.
With this information as a backdrop, let me provide you some additional information on our quarterly metrics and results. As I just noted, currency rate volatility returned in Q3. Although there has been some stabilization on rate year-over-year, rates used for Q3 guidance and full year guidance have weakened against the U.S. dollar. So for this quarter, I provided both U.S. dollar and constant currency as well as described the impact of currency rate volatility from our previous guidance assumptions. We have also provided a table of constant currency results in our earnings press release. In addition, for a more detailed view of our results and the reconciliations of our non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures, please refer to our earnings press release.
We delivered total revenue of $615 million, up 18% or 17% in constant currency. Compared to our September guidance, our result was in the middle of our guidance range, excluding the $3 million impact of FX volatility.
Subscription revenue continued to be the largest driver of our growth at $543 million for the quarter, an increase of 19% year-over-year and 18% in constant currency. This renewable revenue stream now constitutes 88% of total revenue providing a large base of future renewals and up-selling opportunities for new technologies.
We continue to drive high growth across our technology portfolio. Subscription revenue for our infrastructure-related offerings was $431 million, an increase of 16% year-over-year or 14% in constant currency. Our application development related and other emerging technologies subscription revenue was $112 million, an increase of 33% year-over-year or 32% in constant currency. Application development related and other emerging technologies revenue was approximately 18% of total revenue. That's up 210 basis points from a year ago quarter.
On a non-GAAP basis, operating income of $143 million grew 16% year-over-year and non-GAAP operating margin was 23.3%, which is consistent with the operating margin direction we provided on our last call. As a reminder, non-GAAP operating income adjusts for noncash share-based compensation expense, amortization of intangible assets and the transaction costs related to business combinations.
Using our non-GAAP estimated annual effective tax rate of 27%, non-GAAP diluted earnings per share came in at $0.58. This is in line with our guidance after excluding a $0.03 discrete tax benefit, which brought the EPS reported to $0.61 per share, that's up 27% year-over-year.
We ended the quarter with cash and investments of approximately $2 billion. We returned $125 million to shareholders in the quarter through the repurchase of approximately 1.6 million shares of stock. Year-to-date, we have repurchased approximately 23% more shares this year than for the full year last year.
Total deferred revenue at quarter end was $1.7 billion, an increase of $221 million or 15% over the same quarter a year ago. On a constant currency basis, total deferred revenue was up 14%. The total change in deferred revenue from a cash flow statement, which neutralizes most of the impact of currency fluctuations increased by $64 million since the end of Q2.
The rolling 4-quarter billings proxy, which is calculated by adding revenue plus the change in deferred revenue on the cash flow statement for the last 4 quarters, was $635 million, that's up 14% on a constant currency basis and 13% U.S. dollar year-over-year.
Operating cash flow of $136 million for the quarter decreased from a year ago's Q3 operating cash flow of $148 million. Year-to-date operating cash flow is $465 million. Although we continue to deliver strong collections resulting in FX-adjusted day sales outstanding at 58 days, which is down from 59 days in the year ago quarter, overall collections and cash flow were mainly impacted by the similar sales linearity we saw in Q2. I will now review the metrics for the business momentum and some of the large deals in the quarter.
Our geographies saw a continued growth in bookings. This quarter, 57% of the bookings came from the Americas, 27% in EMEA and 16% in Asia Pacific versus a 60%, 26%, 14% split in Q3 last year. The Q3 route-to-market mix was 72% from the channel, 28% from the direct sales force, and that compares to 67% and 33% split in Q3 of last year. This mix shift year-over-year is driven in part by our desire to leverage channel partners that influence customers' buying decisions.
Our proxy for bookings duration was 24 months, higher than the duration last year and our historic duration of 21 months. Customers' demand to extend the length of their commitment with Red Hat, combined with the strength in our cloud-enabling technologies, is an additional proof point of customers choosing to implement hybrid cloud strategies.
Within our 30 largest deals, this marks the first time for this metric that all 30 of them were $2 million or more. 8 of those deals were in excess of $5 million, 3 of those deals were in excess of $10 million. We also had 2 deals of $20 million in the same quarter.
Cross-selling was strong, with over 60% of the deals -- the top 30 deals including 1 or more components from our group of Application development related and other emerging technologies offerings.
Financial services and technology and media were our top verticals in Q3, followed by government and other mainstream customers in sectors such as health care and industrial products.
Looking beyond the top 30 deals to all deals over $1 million, this was a record third quarter for the large deals, with 73 deals over $1 million, which were up 20% year-over-year. For fiscal year 2017 year-to-date, we have seen a 40% increase in the number of deals over $1 million compared to the same period in fiscal year 2016. This traction highlights Red Hat's growing strategic importance in our customers' data centers. And finally, all 25 of the top 25 deals that renewed in the quarter did renew, and the average value of the top 25 deals up for renewal exceeded 120%.
Now I'd like to turn to guidance. Our outlook assumes current business conditions and the foreign exchange rate that have weakened significantly since we last gave guidance in September. We're adjusting our full year revenue guidance to reflect the change in foreign currency rates, our Q3 performance and linearity impact. We are now forecasting $2.397 billion to $2.405 billion, which is up approximately 17% in U.S. dollars. We are reaffirming our non-GAAP operating margin to approximately 23%. We are adjusting the cash flow in the range from $770 million to $785 million to reflect the linearity impact and our forecast of collections and disbursements. We are forecasting full year non-GAAP earnings per share to be approximately $2.27 per share, assuming approximately $1 million to $2 million per quarter forecast for other income; a 27% non-GAAP annual tax rate; and fully diluted share count of 183 million shares.
For Q4 specifically, this implies the following outlook: we expect revenue to be in the range of $614 million to $622 million. This is up 14% in U.S. dollars or approximately 16% in constant currency at the high end of the range. We expect non-GAAP operating margin of approximately 24%, and non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.61 and 181 million fully diluted shares. Based on my annual guidance, the implied cash flow for Q4 is $305 million to $320 million or up 22% to approximately 28%. That's a range of 22% to 28%.
Overall, we remain optimistic about the company's long-term growth opportunity with our position to serve our customers' demand for hybrid cloud solutions. We continue to see strong adoption of our hybrid cloud solutions that span both private and public clouds. And now I'd like to turn it back over to the operator to turn it over to the first question.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttextpreview: I'm just curious, there's some concern around the shift to public cloud. And did you see any pronounced shift that you're seeing in the pipeline that may have caused some of these deals to push? Or is this just timing of transactions and there's nothing r
componenttext: I'm just curious, there's some concern around the shift to public cloud. And did you see any pronounced shift that you're seeing in the pipeline that may have caused some of these deals to push? Or is this just timing of transactions and there's nothing really new competitively that you're seeing?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I haven't seen anything new competitively. We still see really strong growth on public cloud. And yes, I indicated our customers who are working with us around public cloud are growing faster than our other customers. Really, the only place we saw an issu
componenttext: I haven't seen anything new competitively. We still see really strong growth on public cloud. And yes, I indicated our customers who are working with us around public cloud are growing faster than our other customers. Really, the only place we saw an issue, as we talked about, was around the continuing resolution. There were a few large public-sector deals. Specifically on the number on -- we call the CCSP program, which is our on-demand public cloud, we said we would get back to you when we can have a new milestone at $200 million. Expecting that to be kind of second quarter-ish next year.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you -- Jim, can you talk a little bit about the -- we've been seeing larger and larger deals that you're signing. But oversee them, we're seeing like customers not wanting to commit upfront. Can you maybe talk a little bit about the nature of these de
componenttext: Can you -- Jim, can you talk a little bit about the -- we've been seeing larger and larger deals that you're signing. But oversee them, we're seeing like customers not wanting to commit upfront. Can you maybe talk a little bit about the nature of these deals and what's in there, and maybe what's causing people to kind of behave differently than in the past?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, a couple of things. As our portfolio has expanded, and as we had a focus selling beyond RHEL, we were becoming more strategic in customers' portfolio so their willing to commit longer periods of time, so those are committed deals. I think the f
componenttext: Yes. Well, a couple of things. As our portfolio has expanded, and as we had a focus selling beyond RHEL, we were becoming more strategic in customers' portfolio so their willing to commit longer periods of time, so those are committed deals. I think the flip side of that is customers are getting much more used to consumption-based models, and so those very, very large deals they're more comfortable paying a year at a time. I think 4 or 5 years ago when we did a 3-year deal, the majority hadn't paid upfront because they were used to budgeting like they would for a license deal. Now they're getting more used to consumption-ish type deals, and so they're happy to commit to annual payments and so that certainly causing, but they are committed deals. And the other thing I would say is as they get bigger, linearity, as Frank indicated, gets to be more of a challenge. You get more people involved and there is a cycle we always try to break of people wanting to push to the end before they buy. And so as the deals get bigger, that's unfortunately been working against us.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Walter Pritchard with Citi.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Walter Pritchard with Citi.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Frank, related to the question on the longer term or the less commitment. I do note that your long-term deferred actually grew faster year-over-year than your short-term deferred. I guess that might tell me that actually the long-term or the long
componenttext: I guess, Frank, related to the question on the longer term or the less commitment. I do note that your long-term deferred actually grew faster year-over-year than your short-term deferred. I guess that might tell me that actually the long-term or the longer commitments are actually still holding up pretty well. And I'm wondering what are we missing when we look at it that way? It seems like that would tell the story of long-term commitments actually doing quite well.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say overall, long-term commitments are doing well. Again, maybe those aren't billings so they don't even show up in the long-term deferred. But overall, some are paying and therefore billing and therefore show, but a lot aren't, which does mute
componenttext: Well, I'd say overall, long-term commitments are doing well. Again, maybe those aren't billings so they don't even show up in the long-term deferred. But overall, some are paying and therefore billing and therefore show, but a lot aren't, which does mute the relative growth in the long-term deferred versus the strength that we're seeing overall in large deals.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd also note the big -- the government deals that I indicated, you know the government typically does 1 year at a time. And so one of the reasons you saw the short-term deferred issue is those government deals that kind of pushed around the continuing re
componenttext: I'd also note the big -- the government deals that I indicated, you know the government typically does 1 year at a time. And so one of the reasons you saw the short-term deferred issue is those government deals that kind of pushed around the continuing resolution are all -- were all kind of 1-year deals.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Karl Keirstead with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Karl Keirstead with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This question is for Jim or Frank. I know you don't typically guide on billings growth, but I just wanted to ask you about that. We started fiscal '16 you'll recall with a couple of quarters of constant currency billings growth in the 10% range. Then we s
componenttext: This question is for Jim or Frank. I know you don't typically guide on billings growth, but I just wanted to ask you about that. We started fiscal '16 you'll recall with a couple of quarters of constant currency billings growth in the 10% range. Then we saw 3 good quarters, better quarters in the 15%, 20% range. And this quarter, we're back to 10%. And I think you guided next quarter back to the mid-teens. So it seems to be a wide range here, and I'm just wondering whether looking forward the mid-teens billings growth that you guided to for the February quarter is sort of the normal? Or do you expect, given what's happening in terms of invoicing durations that throughout fiscal '18 that 10% level might be the new normal? Any color there might be helpful for everybody.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Karl, so as you mentioned, we don't guide billings primarily because this is challenging and you can see based on what you just said, there's a lot of volatility. And because of that, it's hard for us to actually predict that. If we do get more informatio
componenttext: Karl, so as you mentioned, we don't guide billings primarily because this is challenging and you can see based on what you just said, there's a lot of volatility. And because of that, it's hard for us to actually predict that. If we do get more information over time and we start to see some kind of a trend, we'll take that in consideration and use that to try to forecast. But at this point, we feel it probably wouldn't be appropriate to provide a range from a guidance or even kind of state what would be a considered trend.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Karl, we said over and over again that it's really tough on a quarterly basis because payment terms can vary a lot. If the 2 large deals we had decided to pay upfront, that would have been $27 million or something in that range of incremental billing
componenttext: Yes, Karl, we said over and over again that it's really tough on a quarterly basis because payment terms can vary a lot. If the 2 large deals we had decided to pay upfront, that would have been $27 million or something in that range of incremental billings and long-term deferred revenue. They chose not to. And as we said in the past, we don't want to give significant discounts for people to pay upfront because we don't need the cash.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing, too, which comes up, I mean, the size of the deals, as you start getting larger deal, a deal makes an impact, right? And so whether they close 1 quarter or another can make a big difference on the billing.
componenttext: And the other thing, too, which comes up, I mean, the size of the deals, as you start getting larger deal, a deal makes an impact, right? And so whether they close 1 quarter or another can make a big difference on the billing.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Matt Hedberg with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess for Jim or Frank. From a high level you think longer term here, what's the right way that we should think about balancing growth benefiting from clearly cloud business, but also margin improvement longer term? Any sort of framework we should think
componenttext: I guess for Jim or Frank. From a high level you think longer term here, what's the right way that we should think about balancing growth benefiting from clearly cloud business, but also margin improvement longer term? Any sort of framework we should think about there?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll just go back, Matt, to what we had talked about back at our Analyst Day in June, and I know we've been getting a lot of feedback from many of you on the sell side and also on the buy side looking at that, and we're taking that in consideration. Ri
componenttext: So I'll just go back, Matt, to what we had talked about back at our Analyst Day in June, and I know we've been getting a lot of feedback from many of you on the sell side and also on the buy side looking at that, and we're taking that in consideration. Right now, we're in the midst of planning for FY '18. As you probably saw in the last few quarters, we've seen continued slight improvement in the margin -- in the operating margin. We want to see, again, focused first on the top line growth, emphasizing the new emerging technologies product that's where we're making the investment, that's where we want to see the return to make sure that we can accelerate growth. And with that, we want to make the investments to go along with that and then also continue as all of you have asked, to see slight margin improvement as we continue to focus on that. So we're trying to work through the balance of that whole portfolio for the next year, and as we get more information, I'm sure we'll share that.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Gregg Moskowitz with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Gregg Moskowitz with Cowen and Company.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question for Frank. Just in light of the billings disappointment this quarter, wondering if there's any more color that you can give us. I know this is atypical, but again just under the circumstances, any more color you can give us on the off-bala
componenttext: Just a question for Frank. Just in light of the billings disappointment this quarter, wondering if there's any more color that you can give us. I know this is atypical, but again just under the circumstances, any more color you can give us on the off-balance sheet backlog to perhaps help put this in a little bit better context?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as you know, we provide the off-balance sheet backlog at the end of the year, which we do and plan to do at the end of Q4. I mean, if you look at some of the dynamics of kind of what we talked about, we can't give an exact number. This quarter, we did
componenttext: So as you know, we provide the off-balance sheet backlog at the end of the year, which we do and plan to do at the end of Q4. I mean, if you look at some of the dynamics of kind of what we talked about, we can't give an exact number. This quarter, we did see some slight improvement on off-balance sheet, which did impact the quarter, but we'll have to wait and see how that continues to play out for Q4 and then we'll provide that information at the end of the year.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and as I said a minute ago, 2 deals alone were to $27 million in growth and off-balance sheet backlog. So we'll get into a lot more detail on that in Q4 when we talk about the year.
componenttext: Yes, and as I said a minute ago, 2 deals alone were to $27 million in growth and off-balance sheet backlog. So we'll get into a lot more detail on that in Q4 when we talk about the year.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Michael Turits with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Michael Turits with Raymond James.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take my question to maybe reiterate or ask again what -- maybe a different way, what, I think, Karl asked around whether you -- at this point, do you think of the shorter duration as a trend, and whether or not it would be logical to think of it as a
componenttext: I'll take my question to maybe reiterate or ask again what -- maybe a different way, what, I think, Karl asked around whether you -- at this point, do you think of the shorter duration as a trend, and whether or not it would be logical to think of it as a long-term headwind to billings growth?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mean a longer duration? I'm sorry, I didn't...
componenttext: You mean a longer duration? I'm sorry, I didn't...

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the shorter duration on -- the shorter billings duration. In other words, [indiscernible]. I understand the contract duration is longer. But the shorter -- whether or not the shorter billings duration will be a long-term headwind to billings growth.
componenttext: No, the shorter duration on -- the shorter billings duration. In other words, [indiscernible]. I understand the contract duration is longer. But the shorter -- whether or not the shorter billings duration will be a long-term headwind to billings growth.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say we need a few more quarters to get a sense. We had 2 deals of above 20 this quarter. Those were like really, really big ones. We don't have enough experience to say going forward will more of those pay a year at a time or will they pay upfront
componenttext: I would say we need a few more quarters to get a sense. We had 2 deals of above 20 this quarter. Those were like really, really big ones. We don't have enough experience to say going forward will more of those pay a year at a time or will they pay upfront. So give us another couple of quarters to kind of see. And all I can say right now they're kind of a bit volatile on whether they pay or not. And as we kind of -- if we can kind of define the trend, we're happy to share that with you as we identify one.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Steve Ashley with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Steve Ashley with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What is your assumption around the federal business in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: What is your assumption around the federal business in the fourth quarter?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We expect it to, I'll say, kind of come back to normal. Right around change in administration, which is hard to get people to make decisions. And so it was about $20 million of impact on short-term based on a few large deals that kind of slipped. But thos
componenttext: We expect it to, I'll say, kind of come back to normal. Right around change in administration, which is hard to get people to make decisions. And so it was about $20 million of impact on short-term based on a few large deals that kind of slipped. But those all seem like they're coming along nicely. And so we were kind of expecting to be back at kind of business as usual and kind of back on our plan in the public sector space in Q4.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just -- I guess, trying to understand this a little bit. We're talking about -- people are talking about the long term and people paying you less upfront. But if we really just focused on your short-term billings, which obviously doesn't matter then w
componenttext: I'm just -- I guess, trying to understand this a little bit. We're talking about -- people are talking about the long term and people paying you less upfront. But if we really just focused on your short-term billings, which obviously doesn't matter then whether someone is paying you more than 12 months upfront because it's only getting the stuff that's less than 12 months. You still keep seeing a pretty big deceleration in growth in short-term billings. So I guess I'm just trying to think through if we just take away the long-term deferred aspect and whether or not you get people to pay you upfront or not, that trend seems to be -- continue to decelerate from what used to be the 20s to this quarter was, I think it was 14%. So -- and again, I think Walter has highlighted that long-term deferred are actually growing faster than short-term deferred. So can you help us reconcile all the talk about customers paying you less upfront with what's being indicated by the short-term billings trends because maybe I just don't understand it.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, first off, as I said, there's about a $20 million impact that we said associated with the continuing resolution in the government deals, which is several points of growth there. And again, as our cloud business grows, those get paid in arrears
componenttext: Yes, well, first off, as I said, there's about a $20 million impact that we said associated with the continuing resolution in the government deals, which is several points of growth there. And again, as our cloud business grows, those get paid in arrears versus upfront, so that's also a natural drag to that number. But the biggest kind of 1-quarter hit in terms of a decel this quarter was the $20 million, which is several points of growth just right there. And again, that was all in short term. But again, do recognize our overall business is healthier than you would see in the short term because of also the mix of cloud, which is continuing to grow very, very fast and pays in arrears versus upfront.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Kash Rangan with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Kash Rangan with Bank of America.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, good luck with the next opportunity and happy holidays to everybody. One thing that crossed my mind is this quarter your currency was a bit of a tailwind. Your constant currency was a little bit lower than the reported. So I'm curious what is drivi
componenttext: Frank, good luck with the next opportunity and happy holidays to everybody. One thing that crossed my mind is this quarter your currency was a bit of a tailwind. Your constant currency was a little bit lower than the reported. So I'm curious what is driving the top process behind having a more diminished outlook with respect to the February quarter? Maybe I'm not understanding the currency dynamics because it was a tailwind this quarter and also curious you've talked about linearity changes in the quarter. Was that purely on account of the government deals that slipped or are you seeing something post the election cycle that even in the commercial sector that the linearity is turning out to be a little but different and you don't anticipate that to change. And if that's the case, what could be causing that?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start the second on linearity and I'll let Frank take the currency piece. So the government deals that's left there, they weren't in the quarter at all, so they don't actually impact linearity because they just weren't there. The linearity overa
componenttext: Yes, I'll start the second on linearity and I'll let Frank take the currency piece. So the government deals that's left there, they weren't in the quarter at all, so they don't actually impact linearity because they just weren't there. The linearity overall -- and again, we're continuing to work to improve it, but as the deals get bigger, large deals seem to buyers are programmed to want to buy in the last week because they believe they get the best terms. And frankly, the 2 very, very large deals where 1 was on the last day, and I think that's a natural kind of buying pattern that we see in technology. And when our deals were smaller, they kind of flew under the radar but as they're getting bigger, we're getting the same scrutiny than anyone else would be getting on 8-figure deals. And so we are working to offset that, so I don't mean to have that as an excuse. But I don't know if there's any systemic with what we're doing or the business, I just think that as deals get bigger, they naturally get more time and attention and that naturally drives them to end of quarter because that's when buyers believe they're going to get the best deal.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm not quite sure I get your full question on the currency, but let me just provide a little bit of additional information. So if you look back from a revenue standpoint, Q1, Q2, Q3 and then also what we're assuming for the guide for Q4, and we look a
componenttext: So I'm not quite sure I get your full question on the currency, but let me just provide a little bit of additional information. So if you look back from a revenue standpoint, Q1, Q2, Q3 and then also what we're assuming for the guide for Q4, and we look at the rates and how they've changed over the year. In Q1, we ended up getting a -- this is on revenue, we ended up getting a $3 million benefit for revenue. In Q2, we had a $5 million benefit on currency and revenue. In Q3 this past quarter, we had a $3 million impact, so a hurt to revenue. And then as we said before, taken the rates that we're looking at right now for Q4, it's about 16. So overall for the year, we will be down from a currency perspective about $11 million for the full year based on how currency was positive at the beginning of the year and abruptly changed and really the change occurred in the latter part of Q3 and you'll probably know with some of the other software companies that recently announced they talked about the same type of impact. When you have the type of model that we have, a currency volatility does have a -- could have a significant impact. This is why we have been very transparent all along when it worked in our favor and then also when it's a hurt at the same time.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Kirk Materne with Evercore ISI.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about the customers that are pushing for -- with you all from more of a hybrid perspective. Is there any concentration from verticals? Do you see certain verticals moving at a faster cadence or cert
componenttext: Jim, I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about the customers that are pushing for -- with you all from more of a hybrid perspective. Is there any concentration from verticals? Do you see certain verticals moving at a faster cadence or certain geographies? I was just kind of curious you mentioned those customers were growing the fastest with you. Could you just maybe provide a little more detail where you may be see some concentration either from a vertical or geographic basis in terms of taking on a lot of these newer products?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really pretty broad. As I said, we literally have hundreds of customers this quarter around OpenStack, OpenShift and CloudForm. So it really is broad and significant. We actually had over 50 OpenShift deals alone that were 6 or 7 figures. So really s
componenttext: It's really pretty broad. As I said, we literally have hundreds of customers this quarter around OpenStack, OpenShift and CloudForm. So it really is broad and significant. We actually had over 50 OpenShift deals alone that were 6 or 7 figures. So really strong traction. And obviously kind of that many deals is going to cut across a lot of sectors, so it's pretty broad. If I had to call out a couple of sectors, we're seeing really kind of strong traction in health care like a combination of IoT and connected devices is driving a lot of demand. And so I'd say that standing out is a really super-fast growing vertical. Financial services has always been strong. They're technically sophisticated customer, so we're seeing them. But it'd be hard to actually talk about a specific area because it's just really strong across the board, literally hundreds of deals across kind of all the major verticals.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from John DiFucci with Jefferies.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from John DiFucci with Jefferies.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to come back to the large deals not paying upfront again. Is this -- you mentioned a few deals like that. But is this just from a few deals or was this more systemic and more broadly based across your customer base? Because I think some of the o
componenttext: I'm going to come back to the large deals not paying upfront again. Is this -- you mentioned a few deals like that. But is this just from a few deals or was this more systemic and more broadly based across your customer base? Because I think some of the other questions are trying to get to is this just a couple of things or was this something that is -- might affect other companies, too. And I guess, Jim, for those deals, I just want to be clear. For the years beyond year 1, are they still locked in or are those years optional to pay?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no, no. Those -- let me start off the second one quickly. No those are locked-in commitments, right? It's part of a broad strategy we have to help us over time bring down our overall sales cost is to invest a little more time getting multiyear commitm
componenttext: No, no, no. Those -- let me start off the second one quickly. No those are locked-in commitments, right? It's part of a broad strategy we have to help us over time bring down our overall sales cost is to invest a little more time getting multiyear commitments. Our sales team committee, they're going to sell other products or sell other accounts, so those are committed. What I would say overall is I don't think there's anything systemic. I think it really has to do with larger deals just because of their size or are more likely to pay upfront -- I mean, pay over time. And so I guess, we see it as a trend in the sense that we have more large deals. And so typically, 8-figure deals want to pay overtime versus pay upfront, and we're having more and more of those. And so I wish I could give you a better sense because, again, we don't have that many of those types of deals. And I would say overall, the kind of million-dollar level, those are typically not multiyear deals or if they are, they're still paying upfront. So I think it has more to do with just the absolute size. And so again, it's -- we don't have enough deals to call it a trend, but it wouldn't surprise me that as we do more $20-plus million deals that those will more likely decide to pay over time. I do believe and again, this isn't with great data, this is just talking to customers, I do believe that as customers get more used to consumption models, they're used to paying Amazon, they're used to paying Salesforce and SaaS model. They are getting more comfortable in their budget processes, building in annual payments. We've always sold the subscription but, frankly, I think a lot of our customers thought of it like a license and so they would buy long term and they had budget for it that year and that a project and you pay for a project upfront and yes, there was maintenance, but it was mainly budgeted for project. And so they wanted to pay us upfront. I think more and more as people use SaaS, they are paying over time. And that -- again, that's anecdotal talking to customers. But I do think budget processes in IT are recognizing that more spend is going to OpEx from CapEx. And so naturally, it's less of a discussion of let me write you a big check upfront, people are getting more used to putting it in OpEx. And that's probably a trend you'll see across software companies.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Keith Weiss with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Keith Weiss with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe like a broader picture question. You're talking about more seasonality in your quarters in 2Q and you're seeing that more in Q3 and we're talking a lot about really big deals. If we think about the Red Hat business overall, are we just that much mor
componenttext: Maybe like a broader picture question. You're talking about more seasonality in your quarters in 2Q and you're seeing that more in Q3 and we're talking a lot about really big deals. If we think about the Red Hat business overall, are we just that much more weighted towards big deals? I mean is there any sort of market that you can give us? What percentage of your business today is dependent on the big deals? And how has that trended from a year ago or 3 years ago? Is this just so much more big deal-oriented company than it was 3, 5 years ago?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer is I don't think so. I mean, obviously our deals are bigger because the company is multiple to the size it was 5 years ago. I don't believe the concentration's changed. We do look at that metric, I get it every quarter and I haven't noticed any
componenttext: The answer is I don't think so. I mean, obviously our deals are bigger because the company is multiple to the size it was 5 years ago. I don't believe the concentration's changed. We do look at that metric, I get it every quarter and I haven't noticed anything material in that. I do think there's a dynamic and I heard us -- talking to other CEOs and renewal businesses, it's possible that a deal might slip out of a Q1 into a Q2 or out of a Q2 into Q3, but nothing ever slips out of Q4. And so I think -- and then once it's in the Q4, obviously it's a renewal that's going to happen on that same date either 1 year or 3 years from now. And so this is kind of naturally, once something gets more back-end loaded, it stays there. And so things may slip from again a month 1 to a month 2, right? And so -- and then once it gets there, it never renews early, it renews on that date. And so I do think there's just the dynamic that's causing a little bit more back-end loading as just the deals happen and then they get stuck on that date for renewal. We've experimented around and talk to customers about doing an 11.5-month deal or a 13-month deal or something to move some of those around, but that's kind of playing cute on the margin. I really do still think that because of the renewal nature, once you get a deal stuck towards the end of quarter or in the fourth quarter, it's just hard to move after that because the compelling event on that is the renewal to reup the deal.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Abhey Lamba with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Abhey Lamba with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, just wondering up on a couple of comments you made. I think you mentioned that you're taking steps to fix the linearity of the business. What exactly are you doing to fix it? And how should we kind of -- what are your assumptions for Q4? And also you
componenttext: Jim, just wondering up on a couple of comments you made. I think you mentioned that you're taking steps to fix the linearity of the business. What exactly are you doing to fix it? And how should we kind of -- what are your assumptions for Q4? And also you mentioned there's people asking to pay on consumption basis. So are people asking for payment less than 1 year as well? Or is 1 year the lowest terms or the shortest terms you guys are offering?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of things there. I mean, what we've been experimenting with so far, and let's be honest it's not working great that's why we said we've kind of missed our linearity assumptions. But is -- we've been paying down to the kind of manager, country
componenttext: So a couple of things there. I mean, what we've been experimenting with so far, and let's be honest it's not working great that's why we said we've kind of missed our linearity assumptions. But is -- we've been paying down to the kind of manager, country manager level bonuses around linearity. We haven't want to take it out through the individual sales person because, at this point, we hadn't wanted to kind of get them worried so much about that if they're not worried about serving the customer. And so we've been trying to put in some compensation at kind of the sales manager level to try to drive that behavior. And we're still trying to experiment with getting it right, and we haven't quite gotten it right, which is why in Q4, we are assuming linearity that looks more like Q3, which is a little worse than our plan, which is the reason we pulled revenue down a bit for an assumption of worse linearity than we had originally planned.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So consistent linearity in Q4 as we've seen in Q3 is baked into the forecast or the guidance that we provided.
componenttext: Yes. So consistent linearity in Q4 as we've seen in Q3 is baked into the forecast or the guidance that we provided.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Keith Bachman with Bank of Montreal.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I also wanted to ask about billings in the comment you made about customers looking to perhaps pay a bit less. Could you give us any metrics or evidence on what -- how much billings duration has changed during the course of FY '17 versus '16? Is it months
componenttext: I also wanted to ask about billings in the comment you made about customers looking to perhaps pay a bit less. Could you give us any metrics or evidence on what -- how much billings duration has changed during the course of FY '17 versus '16? Is it months? Is it longer? And is that a way to think about as we try to form our models for next year? At least can you give us, pursuant to Karl Keirstead's question, any kind of thoughts on how -- without any numbers on the dollars with how might billings duration be at risk, if you will, or change during the course of the next fiscal year?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we -- our average contract duration, which is contract, not really billings ratio, is 24 months, which is up from 21 months, so people are making longer-term commitments to us. To be blunt, part of that has to do with how we set our sales comp pla
componenttext: Yes, so we -- our average contract duration, which is contract, not really billings ratio, is 24 months, which is up from 21 months, so people are making longer-term commitments to us. To be blunt, part of that has to do with how we set our sales comp plans. Part of our strategy to over time be more efficient with our go to market is to sign more long-term deals, so we're not having to spend more time on renewals because they're locked in. And we emphasize that more in this year's plan. And so that kind of -- I guess one of the reasons we've gone from 21 to 24, we're still working on what we do for next year. But I do think as we get bigger and people are building things like OpenShift and OpenStack into their long-term infrastructures, they want to do long-term deals with us as well. So we had the commercial terms worked out. So I do think you're likely to see some elevation. Will it stay at 24 or turn into 23? I don't think that's hard for us to be able to say. Let me also come back -- so I missed the second part of the last question around consumption model. We typically do, at minimum, 1-year deals. There are a few specific instances where customers for whatever reason, want to be able to burst on to a cloud for specific types of workloads where we've done some consumption-ish type related deals. But that's a small handful of cases that are part of very, very large existing relationships.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Ed Maguire with CLSA.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Ed Maguire with CLSA.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question about these very large deals. Trying to understand what -- are these coming from customers that are consolidating workloads from other vendors? Are they replacing existing implementations? Or are these new projects? And also, how does th
componenttext: I have a question about these very large deals. Trying to understand what -- are these coming from customers that are consolidating workloads from other vendors? Are they replacing existing implementations? Or are these new projects? And also, how does this growing proportion of large deals tie in with the growing role of bookings coming from the channel? Does that have an impact on the sales cycles of these very large deals, like $10 million and up?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, so the answer on the first part of your question is, frankly, a little bit yes, yes, and yes. There's no brand-new customer who comes in and spends $20 million on it. The typical nature of those large deals are they include a component of rene
componenttext: Sure. Well, so the answer on the first part of your question is, frankly, a little bit yes, yes, and yes. There's no brand-new customer who comes in and spends $20 million on it. The typical nature of those large deals are they include a component of renewal for their existing infrastructure. And that's typically growing because we continue to take share both in Middleware and then operating systems from our -- the other players, our competitors in those areas. But these large wins almost always include a significant new infrastructure component, that's what makes them big, either OpenStack or OpenShift. And so again, a deal of that size, it's not -- like we had a couple of 8-figure OpenShift-alone deals. But typically, the really big deals will be a combination of a renewal that is growing plus one of the big new infrastructure, again, OpenStack or OpenShift is kind of normal. In terms of the channel mix, I don't know if that really changes a lot. Recognize that's a measure around fulfillment. And about half of the channel mix is truly kind of no touch where they're out selling. And that's -- obviously, we really like that because it's a recently low cost of sale. Another chunk of that is fulfillment. So many of our large customers choose to fulfill through a channel partner for ease of contracting, et cetera, et cetera. So I don't really have a major impact on kind of billings or sales cycle in a major way unless, and over time, as part of our strategy, we want to move more to channels in a kind of low-touch or no-touch way, and that's slowly happening over time.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions for me. First on the government business that was delayed because of their continuing resolution legislation. That legislation was completed in late September if I remember it correctly, so it's been 2.5 months now. Can you comment i
componenttext: A couple of questions for me. First on the government business that was delayed because of their continuing resolution legislation. That legislation was completed in late September if I remember it correctly, so it's been 2.5 months now. Can you comment if those deals that have been delayed because of this have now closed should have enough time? And then second, regarding OpenStack, in the last couple of months, we've seen several vendors actually exit or significantly reduce their investment in OpenStack area, HP did that, Mirantis did that, with a lot of layoffs related to that. We're claiming that public cloud has now moved fast for OpenStack to ever close the gap. I know it was one of your key selling points at the investor event earlier. And so I guess the question is how is your level of confidence today around OpenStack versus what it was during the Investor Day? And has there anything changed with respect to the type of customers that you're seeing actually adopting it?

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on your first part of the question about the government deals, as we mentioned earlier, we have high confidence that those deals are -- will close in Q4. So they've continued to progress. When you have your deal with some of the challenges from a budge
componenttext: So on your first part of the question about the government deals, as we mentioned earlier, we have high confidence that those deals are -- will close in Q4. So they've continued to progress. When you have your deal with some of the challenges from a budget standpoint, that delays the whole process, not just the close. And so you have to continue to work that. So we do based on tracking the progress with the accounts team and the customer, we feel confident that those will close in Q4.

headline: Red Hat, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And again, there was a messiness around extending the CR, which was relatively disrupted, though it's now been extended to April. And so we feel comfortable that will allow us to get those deals done. So -- and again, the quarter started -- I mean, this i
componenttext: And again, there was a messiness around extending the CR, which was relatively disrupted, though it's now been extended to April. And so we feel comfortable that will allow us to get those deals done. So -- and again, the quarter started -- I mean, this is all September through November was our quarter, and so the iffiness around that and how long it was going to go were all issues for us as well as the change in administration, which is frozen a lot. On your question around OpenStack, frankly, I think some of the pullback is related to exactly what we've said in the past. Doing OpenStack and not being an operating system vendor is extremely difficult. And so I don't think it should be surprising that the people you see still bullish on OpenStack or Red Hat, SUSE and Canonical, and we feel very good in our ability to compete with them. We're seeing, as we said, a lot of big deals traction along with it. These are large, technically sophisticated customers who are also large users of public cloud. They see us set a workloads, they find it much more economic to run in their own data center. Again, these are typically things where they're not trying to call other services that might be in the public cloud and they are running at scale. And so they are very sophisticated and have a good sense of what makes sense to run on-premise versus what makes sense to run in a hybrid cloud. And so we're seeing really, really good traction there. And obviously, now that we're down to fewer competitors in that space, that's also helped us with our pipeline and outlook as well. So we continue to be very bullish on its role on our portfolio.
